chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Peter Abelard's Ethics: Know Yourself
chunks.latin: PETRI ABAELARDI ETHICA SEU LIBER DICTUS SCITO TE IPSUM.
chunks.english: Peter Abelard's Ethics, or the Book Called Know Yourself.
chunks.notes: Opening title of the work

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ex cod. ms. imperialis monasterii S. Emmerammi Ratisbon. ord. S. Ben. eruit R. D. P. Benedictus Bonetus, Benedictinus Mellicensis; edidit D. Bern. Pezius Thes. Anecd., III, II, 626.)
chunks.english: This text was discovered from a manuscript in the imperial monastery of Saint Emmeram in Regensburg, of the Order of Saint Benedict, by the Reverend Father Benedict Bonetus, a Benedictine of Melk. It was published by Bernard Pez in his Treasury of Anecdotes, volume three, part two, page six hundred and twenty-six.
chunks.notes: Editorial note about the manuscript source

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Prologue: Defining Moral Character
chunks.latin: PROLOGUS.
chunks.english: Prologue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mores dicimus animi vitia vel virtutes quae nos ad mala vel bona opera pronos efficiunt. Sunt autem vitia seu bona non tantum animi, sed etiam corporis; ut debilitas corporis vel fortitudo quam vires appellamus; pigredo vel velocitas, claudicatio vel rectitudo, caecitas vel visio.
chunks.english: By moral character we mean the vices or virtues of the soul that make us prone to evil or good actions. But vices and good qualities belong not only to the soul but also to the body, such as bodily weakness or strength, which we call physical power, sluggishness or speed, lameness or uprightness, blindness or sight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde ad differentiam talium cum dicimus: vitia, praemisimus: animi. Haec autem vitia, scilicet animi, contraria sunt virtutibus, ut injustitia justitiae, ignavia constantiae, intemperatia temperantiae.
chunks.english: Therefore, to distinguish these from such bodily conditions, when we say vices, we specify vices of the soul. These vices of the soul are opposed to virtues, as injustice to justice, cowardice to constancy, intemperance to temperance.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Vices of the Soul Pertaining to Moral Character
chunks.latin: CAP. I. De vitio animi quod ad mores pertinet.
chunks.english: Chapter one: On the vice of the soul that pertains to moral character.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt autem animi quoque nonnulla vitia seu bona, quae a moribus sejuncta sunt; nec vitam humanam vituperio vel laude dignam efficiunt, ut hebetudo animi vel velocitas ingenii; obliviosum vel memorem esse, ignorantia vel scientia.
chunks.english: There are also certain vices or good qualities of the soul that are separate from moral character and do not make human life worthy of blame or praise, such as dullness of mind or quickness of intellect, being forgetful or having a good memory, ignorance or knowledge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae quidem omnia cum aeque reprobis ut bonis eveniant, nihil ad morum compositionem pertinent nec turpem vel honestam efficiunt vitam. Unde bene, cum superius praemisissemus: animi vitia, ad exclusionem talium subjunximus: quae ad mala opera pronos efficiunt, id est voluntatem inclinant ad aliquid, quod minime convenit fieri vel dimitti.
chunks.english: Since all these qualities happen equally to the wicked as to the good, they have nothing to do with the formation of moral character and do not make life shameful or honorable. Therefore we did well when, having first said vices of the soul, we added to exclude such qualities: those that make us prone to evil actions, that is, those that incline the will toward something that is not fitting to do or to leave undone.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Distinguishing Sin from Vice
chunks.latin: CAP. II. Quid distet inter peccatum et vitium inclinans ad malum?
chunks.english: Chapter two: What is the difference between sin and the vice that inclines toward evil?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non est autem hujusmodi animi vitium idem quod peccatum, nec peccatum idem quod actio mala. Verbi gratia iracundum esse, hoc est pronum vel facilem ad irae perturbationem, vitium est et mentem inclinat ad aliquid impetuose et irrationabiliter gerendum, quod minime convenit.
chunks.english: Now this kind of vice of the soul is not the same thing as sin, nor is sin the same thing as an evil action. For example, being irascible, that is, being prone or easily moved to the disturbance of anger, is a vice and inclines the mind to do something impulsively and irrationally, which is not fitting.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hoc autem vitium in anima est, ut videlicet sit ad irascendum, etiam cum non movetur ad iram: sicut claudicatio, unde claudus dicitur homo, in ipso est quando etiam non ambulat claudicando, quia vitium adest etiam cum actio deest.
chunks.english: But this vice exists in the soul, making one prone to anger, even when one is not moved to anger, just as lameness, which makes a person lame, exists in him even when he is not walking with a limp, because the vice is present even when the action is absent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic et multos ad luxuriam sicut ad iram natura ipsa vel complexio corporis pronos efficit; nec tamen in ipso hoc peccant quia tales sunt, sed pugnae materiam ex hoc habent, ut per temperantiae virtutem de se ipsis triumphantes coronam percipiant juxta illud Salomonis: Melior est patiens viro forti, et qui dominatur animo suo expugnatore urbium.
chunks.english: Similarly, nature itself or bodily temperament makes many people prone to lust as well as to anger. Yet they do not sin simply by being such people, but rather they have material for struggle, so that by triumphing over themselves through the virtue of temperance they may receive the crown, according to that saying of Solomon: Better is the patient person than the strong warrior, and one who rules his own spirit than one who conquers cities.
chunks.notes: Biblical reference from Proverbs chapter sixteen, verse thirty-two

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim religio ab homine vinci, sed a vitio turpe existimat. Illud quippe bonorum quoque hominum est; in hoc a nobis declinamus. Hanc nobis victoriam commendans Apostolus, ait: Non coronabitur quis, nisi legitime certaverit. Certaverit, inquam, non tam hominibus quam vitiis resistendo, ne nos videlicet in consensum pertrahant pravum.
chunks.english: For religion considers it shameful to be conquered by vice, not by another human being. Being human is common even to good people; it is in vice that we decline from what we should be. The Apostle, commending this victory to us, says: No one will be crowned unless he has competed lawfully. He has competed, I say, not so much by resisting other people as by resisting vices, lest they drag us into wicked consent.
chunks.notes: Biblical reference from Paul's second letter to Timothy, chapter two, verse five

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quae, etsi homines cessent impugnare, nos non cessant, ut tanto periculosior eorum pugna sit quanto frequentior, et tanto victoria clarior quanto difficilior.
chunks.english: Even if other people cease to attack us, vices do not cease, so that their battle is more dangerous the more constant it is, and victory is more glorious the more difficult it is.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Homines vero quantumcunque praevaleant, nihil vitae nostrae turpitudinis ingerunt, nisi cum more vitiorum et, quasi nobis in vitia conversis, turpi nos consensu subjiciunt. Illis corpori dominantibus, dum liber animus fuerit, nihil de vera libertate periclitatur, nihil obscenae servitutis incurrimus.
chunks.english: But other people, however much they may prevail against us, bring no shame to our lives unless, in the manner of vices and as if turning us into vices themselves, they subject us through shameful consent. When they dominate the body, as long as the mind remains free, nothing of true freedom is endangered, and we incur nothing of disgraceful servitude.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim homini servire, sed vitio turpe est; nec corporalis servitus, sed vitiorum subjectio animam deturpat; quidquid enim bonis pariter et malis commune est nihil ad virtutem vel vitium refert.
chunks.english: For it is shameful to serve vice, not to serve another human being. It is not bodily slavery but subjection to vices that defiles the soul, since whatever is common equally to good and evil people has nothing to do with virtue or vice.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Defining Vice and Sin Precisely
chunks.latin: CAP. III. Quid sit animi vitium et quid proprie dicatur peccatum?
chunks.english: Chapter three: What is a vice of the soul and what is properly called sin?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vitium itaque est quo ad peccandum proni efficimur, hoc est inclinamur ad consentiendum ei quod non convenit, ut illud scilicet faciamus aut dimittamus. Hunc vero consensum proprie peccatum nominamus; hoc est culpam animae, qua damnationem meretur vel apud Deum rea statuitur.
chunks.english: Vice, therefore, is that by which we are made prone to sin, that is, we are inclined to consent to what is not fitting, so that we either do it or leave it undone. This consent we properly call sin, that is, the fault of the soul by which it deserves damnation or is established as guilty before God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est enim iste consensus, nisi Dei contemptus et offensa ipsius? Non enim Deus ex damno, sed ex contemptu offendi potest. Ipse quippe est summa illa potestas quae damno aliquo non minuitur, sed contemptum sui ulciscitur.
chunks.english: For what is this consent but contempt of God and an offense against Him? God cannot be offended by any loss, but He can be offended by contempt. He is that supreme power who is not diminished by any loss, but who avenges contempt of Himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Peccatum itaque nostrum contemptus Creatoris est et peccare est Creatorem contemnere, hoc est id nequaquam facere propter ipsum, quod credimus propter ipsum a nobis esse faciendum; vel non dimittere propter ipsum quod credimus esse dimittendum.
chunks.english: Therefore our sin is contempt of the Creator, and to sin is to despise the Creator, that is, not to do for His sake what we believe should be done for His sake, or not to refrain for His sake from what we believe should be refrained from.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum itaque peccatum diffinimus abnegative, dicentes scilicet: non facere, vel non dimittere quod convenit, patenter ostendimus nullam esse substantiam peccati, quod in Non esse potius quam esse subsistat, velut si tenebras diffinientes dicamus: absentiam lucis, ubi lux habuit esse.
chunks.english: When we define sin negatively, saying it is not doing or not refraining from what is fitting, we clearly show that sin has no substance, that it subsists in non-being rather than being, just as if we were defining darkness we would say: the absence of light where light ought to be.
chunks.notes: Abelard's view that sin is a privation, not a positive reality

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed fortassis inquies, quia et voluntas mali operis peccatum est quae nos apud Deum reos constituit, sicut voluntas boni operis justos facit; ut quemadmodum virtus in bona voluntate, ita peccatum in mala voluntate consistat, nec in non esse tantum, verum etiam in esse, sicut et illa.
chunks.english: But perhaps you will say that the will to do evil is also sin, which makes us guilty before God, just as the will to do good makes us just, so that just as virtue consists in good will, so sin consists in evil will, and exists not only in non-being but also in being, just like virtue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quemadmodum enim volendo facere quod Deo credimus placere ipsi placemus, ita volendo facere quod Deo credimus displicere, ipsi displicemus et ipsum offendere sive contemnere videmur.
chunks.english: For just as by willing to do what we believe pleases God we please Him, so by willing to do what we believe displeases God we displease Him and seem to offend or despise Him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed dico quia, si diligentius attendamus, longe aliter de hoc sentiendum est quam videatur. Cum enim nonnunquam peccemus absque omni mala voluntate, et cum ipsa mala voluntas refrenata, non exstincta, palmam resistentibus pariat et materiam pugnae et gloriae coronam conferat, non tam ipsa peccatum quam infirmitas quaedam jam necessaria dici debet.
chunks.english: But I say that if we consider this more carefully, we must think very differently about it than it appears. For since we sometimes sin without any evil will at all, and since evil will itself when restrained but not extinguished produces the palm of victory for those who resist and provides both the material for struggle and the crown of glory, it should be called not so much sin as a certain necessary weakness.
chunks.notes: Key argument: evil desire is not itself sin, but the occasion for virtuous resistance

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce enim aliquis est innocens, in quem crudelis dominus suus per furorem adeo commotus est, ut eum evaginato ense ad interimendum persequatur. Quem ille diu fugiens, et quantumcunque potest sui occisionem devitans, coactus tandem et nolens occidit eum, ne occidatur ab eo.
chunks.english: Consider this example: there is an innocent man whom his cruel master has attacked in such fury that he pursues him with drawn sword to kill him. The innocent man flees for a long time, avoiding his own death as much as he can, but finally, compelled and unwilling, he kills his master to avoid being killed by him.
chunks.notes: Famous thought experiment in medieval moral philosophy

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicito mihi, quicunque es, quam malam voluntatem habuerit in hoc facto? Volens siquidem mortem effugere, volebat propriam vitam conservare. Sed nunquid haec voluntas mala erat? Non, inquies, haec arbitror; sed illa quam habuerit de occisione domini persequentis.
chunks.english: Tell me, whoever you are, what evil will did he have in this deed? For in wanting to escape death, he wanted to preserve his own life. But was this will evil? No, you say, I don't think so, but rather the will he had concerning killing his pursuing master.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Respondeo: Bene et argute dicis, si voluntatem posses assignare in eo quod asseris. Sed, jam ut dictum est, nolens et coactus hoc fecit, quod quantum potuit vitam incolumem distulit, sciens quoque ex hac interfectione vitae sibi periculum imminere. Quomodo ergo illud voluntarie fecit quod eum ipso etiam vitae suae periculo commisit?
chunks.english: I respond: You speak well and cleverly, if you could identify a will in what you assert. But as already stated, he did this unwillingly and under compulsion, having delayed killing as long as he could while preserving his life, knowing also that this killing would bring danger to his own life. How then did he do this voluntarily when he committed it even at the risk of his own life?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si respondeas ex voluntate id quoque esse factum, cum ex voluntate scilicet mortem evadendi, non dominum suum occidendi, constet in hoc eum esse inductum: nequaquam id refellimus; sed, ut jam dictum est, nequaquam voluntas ista tanquam mala est improbanda, per quam ille, ut dicis, mortem evadere, non dominum voluit occidere.
chunks.english: But if you respond that this too was done from will, since it is clear he was led to this from the will to escape death, not to kill his master, we do not refute this at all. But as already stated, this will, through which he wanted to escape death rather than kill his master, as you say, should in no way be condemned as evil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: et tamen deliquit consentiendo, quamvis coactus timore mortis injustae, interfectioni quam eum potius ferre quam inferre oportuit; gladium quippe accipit per se, non traditum sibi habuit a potestate; unde Veritas: Omnis, inquit, qui acceperit gladium, gladio peribit; hoc est damnationem atque animae suae occisionem ex hac temeritate incurrit.
chunks.english: And yet he did wrong by consenting, although compelled by fear of unjust death, to a killing that he ought rather to have suffered than inflicted. For he took up the sword on his own authority; he did not receive it from legitimate power. Hence the Truth says: Everyone who takes up the sword will perish by the sword, that is, he incurs damnation and the death of his own soul from this rash action.
chunks.notes: Biblical reference from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse fifty-two

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Voluit itaque, ut dictum est, ille mortem evadere, non dominum occidere; sed quia in occisionem consensit, in quam non debuit, hic ejus injustus consensus qui occisionem praecessit peccatum fuit.
chunks.english: Therefore, as stated, he wanted to escape death, not to kill his master. But because he consented to the killing, which he should not have done, this unjust consent of his that preceded the killing was the sin.
chunks.notes: Key conclusion: the sin is the consent, not the desire or the action itself

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si quis forte dicat: Quia voluit interficere dominum suum propter hoc ut mortem evaderet, non ideo simpliciter inferre potest quia voluit eum occidere; veluti si dicam alicui: Quia volo ut habeas cappam meam propter hoc ut des mihi quinque solidos, vel: libenter eam pro pretio isto fieri tuam volo, non ideo concedo quod eam tuam esse velim.
chunks.english: But if someone should say: Because he wanted to kill his master in order to escape death, one cannot simply infer from this that he wanted to kill him, just as if I say to someone: I want you to have my cloak so that you will give me five shillings, or: I gladly want it to become yours for this price, I do not thereby concede that I want it to be yours simpliciter.
chunks.notes: Abelard's analysis of conditional versus absolute willing

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed et si quis in carcere constrictus velit filium suum ibi pro se ponere, ut redemptionem suam perquirat, nunquid ideo simpliciter concedimus quod filium suum in carcerem mittere velit, quod cum magnis lacrymis et cum multis gemitibus sustinere cogitur?
chunks.english: Similarly, if someone imprisoned wants to place his son there in his stead so that the son may seek his ransom, do we thereby concede simply that he wants to send his son into prison, when he is forced to endure this with great tears and many groans?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non utique talis, uti ita dicam, voluntas, quae in magno dolore animi consistit, dicenda est voluntas, sed potius passio. Et tale est; quia hoc vult propter illud, tanquam si diceretur quia quod non vult tolerat, propter illud quod desiderat.
chunks.english: Certainly such a so-called will, which consists in great pain of soul, should not be called will but rather suffering. And it is like this: because he wants this for the sake of that, as if it were said that he endures what he does not want for the sake of what he desires.
chunks.notes: Technical distinction between velle (to will) and pati (to suffer)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic et infirmus uri, vel secari dicitur, ut sanetur, et martyres pati, ut ad Christum perveniant; Christus ipse, ut nos ejus passione salvemur. Non tamen ideo simpliciter concedere cogimur ut hoc velint; nusquam enim passio esse potest, nisi ubi contra voluntatem aliquid fit; nec quisquam in eo patitur, ubi suam implet voluntatem et quod fieri eum oblectat.
chunks.english: So also a sick person is said to be burned or cut in order to be healed, and martyrs to suffer in order to reach Christ, and Christ Himself suffered so that we might be saved by His passion. Yet we are not thereby forced to concede simply that they want this. For there can be no suffering unless something happens contrary to the will, nor does anyone suffer in that in which he fulfills his will and which delights him to have happen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et certe Apostolus, qui ait: Cupio dissolvi, et esse cum Christo, id est ad hoc mori ut ad eum perveniam, ipse alibi commemorat: Nolumus exspoliari, sed supervestiri, ut absorbeatur mortale a vita. Quam etiam sententiam a Domino dictam beatus Augustinus meminit, ubi Petro dixit: Extendes manus tuas et alius te cinget, et ducet quo tu non vis.
chunks.english: And certainly the Apostle, who says: I desire to depart and be with Christ, that is, to die in order to reach Him, elsewhere says: We do not wish to be unclothed but to be clothed over, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life. Blessed Augustine also recalls this saying spoken by the Lord to Peter: You will stretch out your hands and another will gird you and lead you where you do not want to go.
chunks.notes: Biblical references: Philippians chapter one verse twenty-three; Paul's second letter to the Corinthians chapter five verse four; Gospel of John chapter twenty-one verse eighteen

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui etiam juxta infirmitatem humanae naturae assumptam Patri ait: Si possibile est, transeat a me calix iste, verum tamen non sicut ego volo, sed sicut tu. Magnam quippe mortis passionem anima ejus naturaliter formidabat, nec voluntarium ei esse poterat quod poenale sciebat.
chunks.english: Christ also, according to the weakness of the human nature He assumed, said to the Father: If it is possible, let this cup pass from me, yet not as I will but as You will. For His soul naturally feared the great suffering of death, nor could what He knew to be painful be voluntary for Him.
chunks.notes: Biblical reference from the Gospel of Matthew chapter twenty-six verse thirty-nine

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De quo cum alibi Scriptum sit: Oblatus est, quia ipse voluit, aut secundum Divinitatis naturam accipiendum est, in cujus voluntate fuit illum assumptum hominem pati, aut voluit dictum est pro disposuit, juxta illud Psalmistae: Quaecunque voluit fecit.
chunks.english: Since Scripture elsewhere says of Him: He was offered because He Himself willed it, this must be understood either according to His divine nature, in whose will it was that the assumed human nature should suffer, or willed is used for ordained, according to the Psalmist's saying: Whatever He willed He did.
chunks.notes: Biblical references: Isaiah chapter fifty-three verse seven; Psalm one hundred thirteen verse three

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Constat itaque peccatum nonnunquam committi sine mala penitus voluntate, ut ex hoc liquidum sit quod peccatum est voluntatem non dici.
chunks.english: It is therefore clear that sin is sometimes committed without any evil will at all, so that from this it is evident that sin is not to be identified with will.
chunks.notes: Abelard's revolutionary conclusion: sin is consent, not desire or action

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: illi. Sic et illud intelligendum est quod ait Dominus: Qui viderit mulierem ad concupiscendam eam (Matth. V, 28); hoc est, qui viderit sic, ut in concupiscentiae consensum incidat, jam moechatus est in corde suo (Matth. V, 28), etsi non moechatus sit in opere; hoc est, jam peccati reatum habet, etsi adhuc effectu caret.
chunks.english: This is how we should understand what the Lord says: 'Whoever looks at a woman to lust after her,' which is to say in Matthew's Gospel, chapter five, verse twenty-eight. This means: whoever looks in such a way that he falls into consent to lust has already committed adultery in his heart, even if he has not committed adultery in deed. That is, he already bears the guilt of sin, even though he still lacks the outward effect.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Etsi diligenter consideremus, ubicunque opera sub praecepto vel prohibitione concludi videntur, magis haec ad voluntatem vel consensum operum quam ad ipsa opera referenda sunt: alioquin, nihil quod ad meritum pertineat, sub praecepto poneretur; et tanto minus praeceptione sunt digna, quanto minus in nostra potestate sunt constituta. Multa quippe sunt, a quibus operari prohibemur, voluntatem vero semper et consensum in nostro habemus arbitrio.
chunks.english: If we consider carefully, wherever works seem to be included under a commandment or prohibition, these should be referred more to the will or consent regarding works than to the works themselves. Otherwise, nothing pertaining to merit would be placed under a commandment. And commandments would be less worthy of being commanded to the degree that they are less established in our power. For there are many things from which we are forbidden to act, but we always have the will and consent in our own control.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce Dominus ait: Non occides. Non falsum testimonium dices (Deut. V, 17, 20). Quae si de operatione tantum, ut verba sonant, accipiamus, nequaquam reatus interdicitur nec culpa sic prohibetur, sed actio culpae. Non enim hominem occidere peccatum est, nec concumbere cum aliena uxore, quae nonnunquam absque peccato committi possunt; neque enim ille, qui falsum testimonium vult dicere vel etiam in dicendo consentit, dummodo illud non dicat quacunque de causa reticens, reus legis efficitur, si prohibitio hujusmodi de opere, sicut verba sonant, accipiatur.
chunks.english: Consider this: the Lord says in Deuteronomy, chapter five, verses seventeen and twenty: 'You shall not kill. You shall not bear false witness.' If we understand these as referring only to the action, as the words sound, then guilt is by no means forbidden, nor is fault thus prohibited, but rather the action of the fault. For killing a man is not itself a sin, nor is sleeping with another man's wife, since these can sometimes be committed without sin. Indeed, if someone wants to give false testimony or even consents to giving it, as long as he does not actually say it for whatever reason and remains silent, he does not become guilty under the law, if such a prohibition is understood to concern the work, as the words sound.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim dictum est ut non velimus falsum testimonium dicere vel ne in dicendo consentiamus, sed solummodo ne dicamus. Aut cum lex prohibet ne sorores nostras ducamus vel eis permisceamur, nemo qui hoc praeceptum servare possit, cum nemo sorores suas recognoscere queat: nemo, inquam, si de actu potius quam de consensu prohibitio fiat.
chunks.english: For it was not said that we should not want to give false testimony or that we should not consent to giving it, but only that we should not say it. Or when the law forbids us to marry our sisters or have intercourse with them, no one could keep this commandment, since no one can recognize his own sisters. No one, I say, if the prohibition concerns the act rather than consent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum itaque accidit ut quis per ignorantiam ducat sororem suam, nunquid transgressor praecepti est quia facit quod facere lex prohibuit? Non est, inquies, transgressor, quia transgressioni non consensit in eo quod ignoranter egit. Sicut ergo transgressor non est dicendus, qui facit quod prohibetur, sed qui consentit in hoc quod constat esse prohibitum: ita nec prohibitio de opere, sed de consensu est accipienda, ut videlicet cum dicitur: Ne facias hoc vel illud, tale sit: Ne consentias in hoc, vel illo faciendo; ac si dicatur: Ne scienter hoc praesumas.
chunks.english: When it happens therefore that someone through ignorance marries his sister, is he a transgressor of the commandment because he does what the law forbids him to do? He is not a transgressor, you will say, because he did not consent to transgression in what he did unknowingly. Just as therefore one who does what is forbidden should not be called a transgressor, but rather one who consents to what is known to be forbidden, so too the prohibition should be understood not as concerning the work, but as concerning consent. So that when it is said 'Do not do this or that,' it means 'Do not consent to doing this or that,' as if it were said 'Do not knowingly presume to do this.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod et beatus diligenter considerans Augustinus omne peccatum vel prohibitionem ad charitatem, seu cupiditatem potius, quam ad opera reducens ait: Nihil praecipit lex, nisi charitatem et nihil prohibet, nisi cupiditatem. Unde et Apostolus: Omnis lex, inquit, in uno sermone completur: Diliges proximum tuum sicut te ipsum (Rom. XIII, 8, 10). Et rursum: Plenitudo legis est dilectio (ibid.). Nihil quippe ad meritum refert utrum eleemosynam indigenti tribuas et te paratum tribuere charitas faciat; et praesto sit voluntas, cum desit facultas; nec in te remaneat facere quod potes, quocunque praepediaris casu.
chunks.english: Blessed Augustine, carefully considering this and reducing all sin or prohibition to charity, or rather to covetousness, rather than to works, says: 'The law commands nothing except charity and prohibits nothing except covetousness.' Hence also the Apostle says in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter thirteen, verses eight and ten: 'The whole law is fulfilled in one saying: You shall love your neighbor as yourself.' And again: 'Love is the fulfillment of the law.' For it makes no difference to merit whether you give alms to someone in need and charity makes you ready to give, and the will is present when the means is lacking, nor does it remain in you to do what you can, by whatever chance you are prevented.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Constat quippe opera quae fieri convenit aut minime aeque a bonis sicut a malis hominibus geri, quos intentio sola separat. In eodem quippe facto, ut praedictus doctor meminit, in quo videmus Deum Patrem, et Dominum Jesum Christum, videmus et Judam proditorem. Facta quippe est a Deo Patre traditio Filii, facta est et a Filio; facta est et a proditore illo: cum et Pater Filium tradidit, et Filius se ipsum (Rom. VIII, 32; Gal. II, 21), ut Apostolus meminit; et Judas Magistrum.
chunks.english: For it is established that works which ought to be done or not done are performed equally by good men as by evil men, whom intention alone separates. For in the same deed, as that teacher mentioned, in which we see God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, we also see Judas the traitor. For the handing over of the Son was done by God the Father, it was done also by the Son, and it was done by that traitor: since both the Father handed over the Son, and the Son handed over himself, as the Apostle mentions in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter eight, verse thirty-two, and his letter to the Galatians, chapter two, verse twenty-one, and Judas handed over the Master.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fecit ergo proditor quod et Deus; sed nunquid ille bene fecit? Nam etsi bonum, non utique bene vel quod ei prodesse debuerit. Non enim quae fiunt, sed quo animo fiant pensat Deus; nec in opere, sed in intentione meritum operantis, vel laus consistit. Saepe quippe idem a diversis agitur: per justitiam unius et per nequitiam alterius; ut si unum reum duo suspendant, ille quidem zelo justitiae, hic antiquae odio inimicitiae; et cum sit suspensionis eadem actio, et utique uterque quod bonum est fieri et quod justitia exigit agant, per diversitatem tamen intentionis idem a diversis fit, ab uno male, ab altero bene.
chunks.english: Therefore the traitor did what God also did. But did he do it well? For even if it was good, it was certainly not done well or in a way that should benefit him. For God weighs not what is done, but with what spirit it is done. Nor does the merit or praise of the one working consist in the work, but in the intention. For often the same thing is done by different people: through the justice of one and through the wickedness of another. For instance, if two people hang one guilty man, one indeed from zeal for justice, the other from hatred of an old enmity, and though the action of hanging is the same, and each certainly does what is good to do and what justice demands, yet through the diversity of intention the same thing is done by different people, by one badly, by the other well.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis denique ipsum diabolum nihil facere ignoret, nisi quod a Deo facere permittitur, cum vel iniquum punit pro meritis; vel, ad purgationem vel exemplum patientiae, justum aliquem permittitur affligere? Sed quia id quod agere eum Deus permittit, nequitia sua stimulante agit, sic potestas ejus bona dicitur vel etiam justa, ut voluntas ejus semper sit injusta. Hanc enim a Deo accipit, illam a se habet.
chunks.english: Who finally is ignorant that the devil himself does nothing except what God permits him to do, when he either punishes the wicked according to their merits, or is permitted to afflict some just person for purification or as an example of patience? But because what God permits him to do, he does urged on by his own wickedness, thus his power is called good or even just, while his will is always unjust. For he receives the former from God, the latter he has from himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis etiam electorum, in his quae ad opera pertinent, hypocritis potest adaequari? Quis tanta sustinet vel agit amore Dei, quanta illi cupiditate humanae laudis? Quis denique nesciat nonnunquam ea quae Deus prohibet fieri, recte geri vel esse facienda: sicut e contrario nonnulla quandoque praecipit, quae tamen fieri minime convenit?
chunks.english: Who also among the elect, in those things which pertain to works, can be equaled to hypocrites? Who endures or does as much from love of God as they do from desire for human praise? Who finally does not know that sometimes things which God forbids to be done are rightly done or ought to be done, just as conversely he sometimes commands certain things which nevertheless are not fitting to be done?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce enim nonnulla novimus ejus miracula, quibus cum infirmitates curaverit, revelari prohibuit, ad exemplum scilicet humilitatis, ne quis forte de gratia sibi collata simili gloriam appeteret. Nec tamen minus illi qui beneficia illa susceperant, publicare illa cessabant, ad honorem scilicet ejus, qui et illa fecerat et revelari prohibuerat, de qualibus scriptum est: Quanto eis praecipiebat ne dicerent, tanto plus praedicabant, etc. Nunquid tales reos transgressionis judicabis, qui contra praeceptum quod acceperant egerunt atque hoc etiam scienter?
chunks.english: Consider indeed, we know some of his miracles in which, when he had cured infirmities, he forbade them to be revealed, as an example of humility of course, lest anyone perhaps seek glory from a similar grace bestowed upon him. Yet nonetheless those who had received those benefits did not cease to make them public, to the honor of course of him who had both done those things and forbidden them to be revealed, concerning which it is written: 'The more he commanded them not to speak, the more they proclaimed it,' and so forth. Would you judge such people guilty of transgression, who acted against the command which they had received and did this even knowingly?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis eos excuset a transgressione, nisi quia nihil egerunt per contemptum praecipientis, quod ad honorem ipsius facere decreverunt? Dic, obsecro, si praecepit Christus quod praecipiendum non fuit, aut si illi dimiserunt quod tenendum fuit? Fuit bonum praecipi, quod non fuit bonum fieri. Utique et in Abraham accusabis Dominum, cui primum praecepit de immolando filio, quod postmodum ipse inhibuit. Nunquid non bene praecepit Deus id fieri quod non erat bonum fieri? Si enim bonum, quomodo postea prohibitum? Si autem idem et bonum fuit praecipi et bonum prohiberi (nec enim quidquam absque rationabili causa Deus permittit, nedum facere consentit) vides quia sola intentio praecepti, non actio facti Deum excusat, cum id bene praecepit, quod non est bonum fieri.
chunks.english: Who excuses them from transgression, except that they did nothing through contempt of the one commanding, which they decided to do for his honor? Tell me, I beseech you, did Christ command what ought not to have been commanded, or did they neglect what ought to have been kept? It was good to command what was not good to do. And certainly you would also accuse the Lord in the case of Abraham, to whom he first commanded the sacrifice of his son, which he himself afterward prohibited. Did not God rightly command that to be done which was not good to be done? For if it was good, how was it afterward prohibited? But if it was both good to command and good to prohibit (for God permits nothing without reasonable cause, much less consents to its being done), you see that the intention of the command alone, not the action of the deed, excuses God, when he rightly commanded what is not good to be done.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim Deus ad hoc intendebat vel agi praecipiebat ut Abraham filium immolaret; sed ut ex hoc maxime obedientia ejus, et constantia fidei, vel amoris in eum probaretur et in exemplo nobis relinqueretur. Hoc quippe patenter et Dominus ipse postmodum profitetur, cum ait: Nunc cognovi quod timeas Dominum (Gen. XXII, 12); ac si aperte diceret: Ad hoc istud tibi praecepi, ad quod te paratum exhibuisti, ut ab aliis facerem cognosci, quod ante saecula de te ipse cognoveram.
chunks.english: For God did not intend or command this to be done so that Abraham should sacrifice his son, but so that from this his obedience, and the constancy of his faith, or his love for him might be proven and left to us as an example. For the Lord himself afterward openly declares this when he says in the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-two, verse twelve: 'Now I know that you fear the Lord,' as if he openly said: 'I commanded this to you for this purpose, to which you showed yourself ready, so that I might make known to others what I myself had known about you before the ages.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recta igitur haec intentio Dei fuit in facto, quod rectum non fuit; et sic recta prohibitio ejus in illis quae diximus quae ad hoc prohibuit, non ut prohibitio teneretur, sed ut vitandae inanis gloriae nobis infirmis exempla darentur. Praecepit itaque Deus quod fieri bonum non fuit; sicut e contrario prohibuit quod fieri bonum fuit. Et sicut ibi excusat eum intentio, ita et hic eos qui praeceptum opere non impleverunt. Sciebant quippe non ob hoc eum praecepisse, ut teneretur, sed ut praedictum exemplum praeponeretur. Salva itaque voluntate jubentis, non eum contempserunt, cujus voluntati se non esse contrarios intellexerunt.
chunks.english: Therefore this intention of God was right in the deed that was not right. And thus his prohibition was right in those things we mentioned, which he prohibited for this purpose, not that the prohibition should be kept, but that examples might be given to us weak ones for avoiding vain glory. Therefore God commanded what was not good to be done, just as conversely he prohibited what was good to be done. And just as there intention excuses him, so here it excuses those who did not fulfill the command in action. For they knew that he had not commanded this so that it should be kept, but so that the aforementioned example might be set before us. Therefore, with the will of the commander preserved, they did not despise him whose will they understood themselves not to be contrary to.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo opera magis quam intentionem pensemus, videbimus nonnunquam contra praeceptum Dei non solum velle fieri, verum etiam fieri aliquid et hoc scienter, sine ullo reatu peccati; nec malam voluntatem vel actionem ideo esse dicendam, quia praeceptum Dei non servat in opere, cum a voluntate praecipientis non discrepat ejus intentio, cui praeceptio fit. Sic enim intentio jubentis excusat ipsum, qui praecipit fieri quod tamen minime convenit fieri; ita et eum cui fit praeceptio excusat charitatis intentio.
chunks.english: If therefore we weigh works more than intention, we shall see that sometimes, not only wanting something done against God's command but even doing it, and this knowingly, occurs without any guilt of sin. Nor should will or action be called evil because it does not keep God's command in the work, when the intention of the one to whom the command is given does not differ from the will of the one commanding. For just as the intention of the one commanding excuses him who commands that to be done which nevertheless is not fitting to be done, so also the intention of charity excuses the one to whom the command is given.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut ergo brevi conclusione supra dicta colligam, quatuor sunt quae praemisimus, ut ab invicem ipsa diligenter distingueremus: vitium scilicet animi, quod ad peccandum pronos efficit; ac postmodum ipsum peccatum, quod in consensu mali, vel contemptu Dei statuimus; deinde mali voluntatem malique operationem. Sicut autem non idem est velle, quod voluntatem implere, ita non idem est peccare, quod peccatum perficere. Illud quippe de consensu animi quo peccamus, hoc de effectu operationis est accipiendum, cum videlicet illud in quo prius consensimus, opere implemus.
chunks.english: So therefore, to gather together what has been said above in a brief conclusion, there are four things which we have set forth, so that we might carefully distinguish them from one another: namely the vice of the soul, which makes us prone to sin; and afterward sin itself, which we define as consent to evil or contempt of God; then evil will and evil operation. But just as willing is not the same as fulfilling the will, so sinning is not the same as completing sin. For the former should be understood as concerning the consent of the soul by which we sin, the latter as concerning the effect of the operation, when namely we fulfill in action that to which we previously consented.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum ergo peccatum vel tentationem tribus modis dicimus peragi, suggestione scilicet, delectatione, consensu, ita est intelligendum: quod ad operationem peccati per haec tria frequenter deducimur, sicut in primis contigit parentibus. Persuasio quippe diaboli praecessit, cum ex gustu vetitae arboris immortalitatem promisit; delectatio successit, cum mulier videns lignum pulchrum et ipsum intelligens suave ad vescendum, in concupiscentiam ejus exarsit, cibi voluptate quam credebat correpta. Quae cum reprimere concupiscentiam deberet, ut praeceptum servaret, consentiendo in peccatum tracta est.
chunks.english: When therefore we say that sin or temptation is carried out in three ways, namely by suggestion, delight, and consent, it should be understood thus: that we are frequently led to the operation of sin through these three things, just as happened to our first parents. For the persuasion of the devil preceded, when he promised immortality from tasting the forbidden tree. Delight followed, when the woman, seeing the tree was beautiful and understanding it was pleasant to eat, was inflamed with desire for it, seized by the pleasure of the food which she believed. When she should have restrained her desire in order to keep the commandment, she was drawn into sin by consenting.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod etiam peccatum cum per poenitentiam deberet corrigere, ut veniam mereretur, ipsum denique consummavit in opere; et ita tribus gradibus ad perpetrandum peccatum incessit. Sic et nos frequenter non ad peccandum, sed ad peccati perpetrationem, iisdem passionibus pervenimus, suggestione scilicet, hoc est, exhortatione alicujus non exterius incitantis ad aliquid agendum, quod non convenit. Quod quidem agere si delectabile noverimus, ante ipsum etiam factum ipsius facti delectatione mens nostra corripitur et in ipsa cogitatione per delectationem tentamur.
chunks.english: And when she should have corrected that sin through repentance so as to merit forgiveness, she finally consummated it in deed. And thus she proceeded through three stages to the perpetration of sin. So also we frequently arrive not at sinning itself, but at the perpetration of sin, through these same stages: namely by suggestion, that is, by the exhortation of someone outside inciting us to do something which is not fitting. If we know that doing this thing is delightful, even before the deed itself our mind is seized by delight in the deed, and in the very thought we are tempted by delight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cui videlicet delectationi dum assentimus per consensum, peccamus. His tandem tribus ad operationem peccati pervenimus.
chunks.english: When we assent to this delight through consent, we sin. Finally, through these three stages we arrive at the operation of sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt, qui suggestionem carnis etiamsi persona suggerens desit, comprehendi nomine suggestionis velint, veluti si quis, visa muliere, in concupiscentiam ejus incidat. Sed haec profecto suggestio nihil aliud quam delectatio videtur esse dicenda; quam quidem delectationem quasi necessariam factam et caeteras hujusmodi, quas non peccatum esse supra meminimus, humanam tentationem Apostolus vocat cum ait: Tentatio vos non apprehendat nisi humana. Fidelis autem Deus, qui non patietur vos tentari supra id quod potestis; sed faciet cum tentatione etiam proventum ut possitis sustinere (I Cor. X, 13).
chunks.english: There are those who wish suggestion of the flesh, even if the person suggesting is absent, to be included under the name of suggestion, as for instance if someone, having seen a woman, falls into desire for her. But this suggestion surely seems to be nothing other than delight. And indeed this delight, made as it were necessary, and other such delights, which we mentioned above are not sin, the Apostle calls human temptation when he says in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter ten, verse thirteen: 'Let no temptation seize you except what is human. But God is faithful, who will not permit you to be tempted beyond what you can bear, but will make with the temptation also a way out so that you may be able to endure it.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tentatio autem generaliter dicitur quaecunque inclinatio animi ad aliquid agendum quod non convenit, sive illa voluntas sit sive consensus. Humana vero tentatio dicitur, sine qua jam humana infirmitas vix aut nunquam subsistere potest, ut concupiscentia carnalis, vel delectabilis cibi desiderium, a quibus se liberari postulabat qui dicebat: De necessitatibus meis erue me, Domine (Psal. XXIV, 17); hoc est, de his tentationibus concupiscentiarum, quae quasi naturales ac necessariae jam factae sunt, ne ad consensum pertrahant, vel vita ista, plena tentationibus, finita prorsus eis caream.
chunks.english: Now temptation is generally called any inclination of the soul toward doing something which is not fitting, whether that be will or consent. But human temptation is called that without which human weakness can now scarcely or never subsist, such as carnal desire or the desire for delightful food, from which he who said this sought to be freed: 'Deliver me from my necessities, O Lord,' that is to say, from Psalm twenty-four, verse seventeen. This means: from these temptations of desires, which have become as it were natural and necessary, lest they draw me to consent, or when this life, full of temptations, is finished, I may wholly lack them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod ergo ait Apostolus: Tentatio vos non apprehendat nisi humana, consimilis sententia est ac si diceret: Si inclinatur animus ex delectatione quae est, ut diximus, humana tentatio, non usque ad consensum pertrahat, in quo peccatum consistit. Quod quasi aliquis quaereret, qua nostra virtute concupiscentiis istis possemus resistere? Fidelis, inquit, Deus qui non patietur vos tentari. Tanquam si diceret: De ipso potius est confidendum, quam de nobis praesumendum, qui, nobis auxilium promittens, in omnibus verax est promissis, quod est eum fidelem esse, ut ei scilicet de omnibus adhibenda sit fides.
chunks.english: Therefore what the Apostle says, 'Let no temptation seize you except what is human,' is a similar sentiment as if he said: If the soul is inclined by delight, which is, as we said, human temptation, let it not drag you all the way to consent, in which sin consists. As if someone were asking: By what virtue of ours could we resist these desires? God is faithful, he says, who will not permit you to be tempted. As if he were saying: In him rather should we trust than presume upon ourselves, who, promising us help, is truthful in all his promises, which is what it means for him to be faithful, so that faith should be placed in him concerning all things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc vero nos non patitur tentari supra id quod possumus, cum per misericordiam suam ita hanc tentationem humanam temperat, ut non plus ad peccatum premat quam perferre possimus, ei videlicet resistendo. Tunc autem insuper hanc ipsam tentationem nobis convertit ad commodum, dum per eam sic nos exercet, ut deinceps cum occurrerit, minus gravare possit; et jam minus impetum hostis timeamus, de quo jam triumphavimus, et perferre novimus. Omnis quippe pugna, quam nondum experti sumus, gravius sustinemus, et amplius formidamus. Cum vero in consuetudinem victoribus venerit, pariter virtus ejus et metus evanescit.
chunks.english: Then truly he does not permit us to be tempted beyond what we can bear, when through his mercy he so tempers this human temptation that it does not press toward sin more than we can bear, namely by resisting it. But then moreover he converts this very temptation to our advantage, while through it he so exercises us that afterward when it occurs, it may weigh upon us less. And now we fear less the assault of the enemy over whom we have already triumphed and know how to endure. For every battle which we have not yet experienced, we endure more heavily and fear more greatly. But when it has become customary for the victors, both its strength and fear vanish together.
chunks.notes: The Latin mentions 'Vide supra' which appears to be a cross-reference note

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Demonic Suggestions and Natural Temptations
chunks.latin: CAP. IV. De suggestionibus daemonum.
chunks.english: Chapter Four: On the Suggestions of Demons

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt autem suggestiones non solum hominum, sed et daemonum; quia et isti nonnunquam ad peccatum nos incitant non tam verbis quam factis. Periti quippe naturae rerum tam ingenii subtilitate quam longa experientia (unde et daemones, hoc est scientes sunt appellati,) noverunt vires rerum naturales, unde ad libidinem vel ad caeteros impetus humana infirmitas facile possit commoveri.
chunks.english: Now suggestions come not only from men, but also from demons, because these too sometimes incite us to sin not so much by words as by deeds. For being skilled in the nature of things both by subtlety of intellect and by long experience (whence they are called demons, that is, knowing ones), they know the natural powers of things, by which human weakness can easily be stirred to lust or to other impulses.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic et in languorem, Deo permittente, nonnunquam aliquos mittunt ac postmodum supplicantibus sibi remedia conferunt et frequenter cum cessant laedere, curare creduntur. Denique in Aegypto multa contra Moysen mirabiliter operari per magos sunt permissi, ac quidem, naturali vi rerum quam noverant, non tam eorum quae faciebant creatores dicendi quam compositores: veluti si quis juxta documentum Virgilii tunsa carne tauri apes inde fieri laborando efficeret, non tam apum creator quam naturae praeparator dicendus esset.
chunks.english: Thus too, with God permitting, they sometimes send people into illness and afterward confer remedies upon those begging them, and often when they cease to harm, they are believed to heal. Indeed, in Egypt they were permitted to work many wonders against Moses through magicians, and indeed by the natural power of things which they knew, they should be called not so much creators of what they made as composers. Just as if someone, following Virgil's instruction, should by effort make bees come forth from the pounded flesh of a bull, he should be called not so much a creator of bees as a preparer of nature.
chunks.notes: Reference is to Virgil's Georgics Book Four, verse 310

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex hac itaque rerum peritia quam habent in earum naturis daemones, nos in libidinem vel caeteras animi passiones commovent, quacunque arte nobis ignorantibus eas admovendo, sive in gustu, sive in stratu eas ponendo, vel quolibet modo eas interius vel exterius collocando. Multae quippe sunt in herbis vel seminibus, vel tam arborum, quam lapidum naturis vires ad commovendos vel pacandos animos nostros aptae, quas qui diligenter nossent, hoc agere facile possent.
chunks.english: Therefore from this skill in things which demons have in their natures, they stir us to lust or other passions of the soul, applying them to us by whatever art while we are ignorant, whether placing them in taste or in bedding, or in whatever way arranging them internally or externally. For there are many powers in herbs or seeds, or in the natures of both trees and stones, suitable for stirring or calming our souls, which those who knew them carefully could easily accomplish.

chunks.chapter_title: Why Sinful Deeds Receive Greater Punishment Than Sinful Intent
chunks.latin: CAP. V. Cur opera peccati magis quam ipsum puniatur?
chunks.english: Chapter Five: Why the Works of Sin Are Punished More Than the Sin Itself

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt etiam qui non mediocriter moventur, cum audiunt nos dicere, opus peccati non proprie peccatum dici, vel quidquam non addere ad peccati augmentum; cur gravior satisfactio poenitentibus injungatur de operis effectu, quam de culpae reatu. Quibus quidem hoc primum respondeo, cur non praecipue mirentur pro eo quod nonnunquam magna satisfactionis instituitur poena, ubi nulla intercesserit culpa; et eos quandoque punire debeamus, quos innocentes scimus?
chunks.english: There are also those who are moved considerably when they hear us say that the work of sin is not properly called sin, or that it adds nothing to the increase of sin. Why is a more severe satisfaction imposed on penitents for the effect of the work than for the guilt of the fault? To these indeed I respond first: Why do they not especially wonder at the fact that sometimes a great penalty of satisfaction is imposed where no fault has intervened, and that we should sometimes punish those whom we know to be innocent?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce enim pauper aliqua mulier infantulum habet lactentem, nec tantum indumentorum habet, ut et parvulo in cunis et sibi sufficere possit. Miseratione itaque infantuli commota eum sibi apponit, ut propriis insuper foveat pannis et tandem infirmitate ejus vi naturae superata opprimere cogitur, quem amore summo amplectitur: Habe, inquit, Augustinus, charitatem et fac quidquid vis. Quae tamen pro satisfactione cum ad episcopum venerit, gravis ei poena injungitur non pro culpa quam commiserit, sed ut ipsa deinceps vel caeterae feminae in talibus providendis cautiores reddantur.
chunks.english: Consider indeed: some poor woman has a nursing infant, and does not have enough clothing that she can provide for both the little one in the cradle and for herself. Therefore, moved by compassion for the infant, she places him next to her so that she may also warm him with her own garments, and finally, overcome by weakness and the force of nature, she is compelled to smother the one she embraces with the greatest love. Augustine says: 'Have charity and do what you will.' Yet when she comes to the bishop for satisfaction, a severe penalty is imposed upon her, not for a fault which she committed, but so that she herself afterward or other women may be made more cautious in providing for such situations.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nonnunquam etiam contingit aliquem ab inimicis suis apud judicem accusari et tale quid illi imponi, unde illum innocentem esse judex cognoscit. Quia tamen illi instant et audientiam in judicio postulant, statuto die causam ingrediuntur, testes proferunt licet falsos ad eum quem accusant, convincendum; quos tamen testes cum nequaquam judex manifestis de causis refellere possit, eos suscipere lege compellitur; et eorum probatione suscepta punire innocentem debet, qui puniri non debet.
chunks.english: Sometimes also it happens that someone is accused by his enemies before a judge, and such a charge is brought against him that the judge knows him to be innocent. Because however they press him and demand a hearing in court, on the appointed day they enter the case, they bring forward witnesses, though false ones, to convict the one they accuse. When however the judge can in no way refute these witnesses for evident reasons, he is compelled by law to accept them. And having accepted their testimony, he must punish the innocent man who ought not to be punished.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Itaque punire debet, licet non meruerit, cum tamen lege praecipiente hoc juste judex peragit. Ex his itaque liquet nonnunquam poenam rationabiliter injungi ei, in quo nulla culpa praecessit. Quid igitur mirum si ubi culpa praecesserit, operatio subsecuta poenam augeat apud homines in hac vita, non apud Deum in futura?
chunks.english: Therefore he must punish, though the man has not deserved it, yet the judge performs this justly when the law commands it. From these cases therefore it is clear that sometimes punishment is reasonably imposed on one in whom no fault preceded. What therefore is surprising if where fault has preceded, the ensuing action increases punishment among men in this life, though not with God in the future?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim homines de occultis, sed de manifestis judicant, nec tam culpae reatum quam operis pensant effectum. Deus vero solus, qui non tam quae fiunt quam quo animo fiant attendit, veraciter in intentione nostra reatum pensat et vero judicio culpam examinat: unde et probator cordis et renum (Jer. XX, 12) dicitur, et in abscondito videre (Matth. VI, 4). Ibi enim maxime videt, ubi nemo videt; quia in puniendo peccatum non opus attendit, sed animum; sicut nos e converso non animum, quem non videmus, sed opus quod novimus.
chunks.english: For men judge not of hidden things but of manifest things, nor do they weigh so much the guilt of the fault as the effect of the work. But God alone, who attends not so much to what is done as with what spirit it is done, truly weighs guilt in our intention and examines fault with true judgment. Hence he is called the tester of heart and reins, as it says in the prophet Jeremiah, chapter twenty, verse twelve, and he sees in secret, as in Matthew's Gospel, chapter six, verse four. For there he sees especially where no one sees, because in punishing sin he does not attend to the work but to the soul, just as we conversely attend not to the soul, which we do not see, but to the work which we know.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde saepe per errorem, vel per legis, ut diximus, coactionem, innocentes punimus, vel noxios absolvimus. Probator et cognitor cordis et renum dicitur Deus; hoc est, quarumlibet intentionum ex affectione animae, vel infirmitate, seu delectatione carnis provenientium.
chunks.english: Hence often through error, or through compulsion of law, as we said, we punish the innocent or absolve the guilty. God is called the tester and knower of heart and reins, that is, of whatever intentions proceeding from the affection of the soul, or from weakness, or from delight of the flesh.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Spiritual and Carnal Sins Distinguished
chunks.latin: CAP. VI. De peccatis spiritualibus vel carnalibus.
chunks.english: Chapter Six: On Spiritual or Carnal Sins

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum enim omnia peccata sint animae tantum, non carnis (ibi quippe culpa et contemptus Dei esse potest, ubi ejus notitia et ratio consistere habet) quaedam tamen peccata spiritualia, quaedam carnalia dicuntur, hoc est, quaedam ex vitiis animae, quaedam ex infirmitate carnis provenientia.
chunks.english: For although all sins are of the soul only, not of the flesh (for guilt and contempt of God can exist there where knowledge of him and reason reside), yet some sins are called spiritual, some carnal, that is, some proceeding from vices of the soul, some from weakness of the flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quamvis concupiscentia solius sit animae, sicut et voluntas (non enim concupiscere vel desiderare aliquid nisi volendo possumus), concupiscentia tamen carnis, sicut et concupiscentia spiritus dicitur: Caro enim, ait Apostolus, concupiscit adversus spiritum, et spiritus adversus carnem (Gal. V, 7); hoc est, ex delectatione quam habet in carne, quaedam appetit, quae tamen judicio rationis refugit, vel appetenda censet.
chunks.english: And although desire belongs to the soul alone, just as will does (for we cannot desire or want anything except by willing), yet desire of the flesh is spoken of, just as desire of the spirit is. For the Apostle says in his letter to the Galatians, chapter five, verse seven: 'The flesh desires against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh.' This means: from the delight which it has in the flesh, it desires certain things which nevertheless it flees by the judgment of reason, or judges ought to be desired.
chunks.notes: The verse citation appears to be Galatians 5:17, not 5:7 - likely a manuscript error

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Why God Is Called the Inspector of Heart and Reins
chunks.latin: CAP. VII. Cur Deus dicatur inspector cordis et renum?
chunks.english: Chapter Seven: Why God Is Said to Be the Inspector of Heart and Reins

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Juxta igitur haec duo, concupiscentiam carnis et concupiscentiam animae, quae praemisimus, probator cordis et renum dictus est Deus, hoc est, inspector intentionum vel consensuum inde provenientium. Nos vero qui hoc discutere ac dijudicare non valemus, ad opera maxima judicium nostrum convertimus, nec tam culpas, quam opera punimus, nec in aliquo tam quod ejus animae nocet, quam quod aliis nocere possit vindicare studemus, ut magis publica praeveniamus damna, quam singularia corrigamus, juxta quod et Dominus Petro ait: Si peccaverit in te frater tuus, corripe illum inter te et ipsum solum (Matth. XVIII, 15).
chunks.english: According to therefore these two things, desire of the flesh and desire of the soul, which we set forth above, God is called tester of heart and reins, that is, inspector of intentions or consents proceeding from them. But we who are not able to examine and judge this, turn our judgment chiefly to works, and we punish not so much faults as works, nor do we strive to punish in anyone so much what harms his soul as what can harm others, so that we may rather prevent public harms than correct individual ones, according to what the Lord also says to Peter in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eighteen, verse fifteen: 'If your brother sins against you, correct him between you and him alone.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est: peccaverit in te, quasi non in alium, ut magis injurias nobis, quam aliis illatas corrigere vel vindicare debeamus? Absit. Si peccaverit in te, dixit, cum manifeste agit unde te per exemplum corrumpere possit. Quod si enim in se tantum peccat, cum culpa ejus occulta eum solum reum constituit, non ad reatum alios quantum in se est per exemplum trahit.
chunks.english: What does 'sins against you' mean, as if not against another, so that we should correct or punish injuries brought upon us rather than upon others? Far from it. 'If he sins against you,' he said, when he acts openly in a way that can corrupt you by example. For if he sins only against himself, when his hidden fault makes him alone guilty, he does not drag others to guilt as far as he is concerned through his example.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Etsi enim desunt; qui malam ejus actionem imitentur, vel etiam cognoverint, actio tamen ipsa magis quam animi culpa castiganda est apud homines, quia plus offensae contrahere potuit, et perniciosius per exemplum fieri, quam culpa latens animi. Omne namque quod in communem perniciem, vel in publicum redundare potest incommodum, castigatione majori est puniendum, et quod contrahit majorem offensam, graviorem inter nos promeretur poenam, et majus hominum scandalum, majus inter homines incurrit supplicium, etsi levior praecessit culpa.
chunks.english: For even if there are lacking those who might imitate his evil action or even have known of it, yet the action itself rather than the fault of the soul should be chastised among men, because it could contract more offense and be done more perniciously through example than the hidden fault of the soul. For everything that can result in common harm or in public inconvenience should be punished with greater chastisement, and what contracts greater offense deserves heavier punishment among us, and greater scandal of men incurs greater punishment among men, even if a lighter fault preceded.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ponamus enim aliquem coitu suo mulierem aliquam corrupisse in ecclesia: quod cum ad aures populi delatum fuerit, non tantum de violatione feminae, ac veri templi Dei, quantum de infractione corporalis templi commoventur; cum tamen gravius sit in mulierem, quam in parietes praesumere, et homini quam loco injuriam inferre. Et incendia domorum majori poena vindicamus, quam in peracta fornicatione, cum longe apud Deum haec illis habentur graviora.
chunks.english: For let us suppose that someone has corrupted some woman by his intercourse in a church. When this has been reported to the ears of the people, they are moved not so much by the violation of the woman and of the true temple of God, as by the breaking of the physical temple, although it is more serious to presume upon a woman than upon walls, and to inflict injury upon a human being than upon a place. And we punish the burning of houses with greater penalty than completed fornication, although these latter are held far more serious before God than those former.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et haec quidem non tam justitiae debito, quam dispensationis aguntur temperamento, ut, quemadmodum diximus, publica praeveniendo damna communi consulamus utilitati. Saepe igitur minima peccata majoribus poenis vindicamus, non tam aequitate justitiae attendentes quae culpa praecesserit, quam discretione providentiae cogitantes quanta hinc contingere possit incommoditas, si leviter puniatur.
chunks.english: And these things indeed are done not so much by the requirement of justice as by the moderation of administration, so that, as we said, by preventing public harms we may provide for the common utility. Therefore we often punish the smallest sins with greater penalties, attending not so much to the equity of justice regarding what fault preceded, as thinking with the discretion of providence how much inconvenience might result from this if it is punished lightly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Culpas itaque animi divino reservantes judicio, effecta earum, de quibus judicare habemus, prosequimur nostro, dispensationem in talibus, hoc est, prudentiae quam diximus rationem magis quam aequitatis attendentes puritatem. Deus vero unius cujusque poenam secundum culpae quantitatem disponit, et quicunque ipsum aequaliter contemnunt, aequali postmodum poena puniuntur cujuscunque conditionis aut professionis sint.
chunks.english: Therefore, reserving faults of the soul to divine judgment, we pursue with our own judgment their effects, about which we have to judge, attending in such matters to administration, that is, to the reasoning of prudence which we mentioned, rather than to the purity of equity. But God arranges the punishment of each according to the quantity of fault, and whoever equally despise him are afterward punished with equal penalty, of whatever condition or profession they may be.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim monachus et laicus in consensum fornicationis pariter veniant, et mens quoque laici in tantum sit accensa, ut neque ipse, si monachus esset, pro reverentia Dei ab ista turpitudine desisteret, eamdem quam monachus poenam meretur. Sic et de illis sentiendum est, quorum alter manifeste peccans multos scandalizat, ac per exemplum corrumpit; alter vero cum occulte peccet, soli sibi nocet.
chunks.english: For if a monk and a layman equally come to consent to fornication, and the mind of the layman also is so inflamed that he himself, even if he were a monk, would not desist from this shameful act out of reverence for God, he deserves the same punishment as the monk. So also should we think about those of whom one, sinning openly, scandalizes many and corrupts them by example, while the other, sinning secretly, harms only himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim qui occulte peccet, in eodem, quo ille, proposito et pari contemptu Dei existit, ut quod alios non corrumpit, fortuitu magis eveniat, quam ipse propter Deum dimittat, qui nec sibi ipsi propter Deum temperat, profecto pari reatu apud Deum constringitur. Solum quippe animum in remuneratione boni vel mali, non effecta operum Deus attendit, ne quid de culpa vel bona voluntate nostra proveniat, pensat, sed ipsum animum in proposito suae intentionis, non in effectu exterioris operis dijudicat.
chunks.english: For if one who sins secretly exists in the same purpose and equal contempt of God as that other, so that his not corrupting others happens more by chance than because he himself refrains for God's sake, who does not even restrain himself for God's sake, he is certainly bound by equal guilt before God. For God attends only to the soul in recompensing good or evil, not to the effects of works. He weighs not what proceeds from our fault or good will, but judges the soul itself in the purpose of its intention, not in the effect of outward work.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Opera quippe, quae, ut praediximus, aeque reprobis ut electis communia sunt, omniaque in se indifferentia, nec nisi pro intentione agentis bona vel mala dicenda sunt, non videlicet quia bonum vel malum sit ea fieri, sed quia bene vel male fiunt, hoc est, ea intentione qua convenit fieri, aut minime.
chunks.english: For works, which, as we said before, are equally common to the reprobate as to the elect, and all are in themselves indifferent, nor should they be called good or evil except according to the intention of the doer, not because it is good or evil that they be done, but because they are done well or badly, that is, with the intention by which they ought to be done, or not at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam, ut beatus meminit Augustinus, ipsum malum esse, bonum est, cum eo quoque bene utatur Deus, nec aliter ipsum esse permittat, cum tamen ipsum nequaquam sit bonum. Cum itaque dicimus intentionem hominis bonam, et opus illius bonum, duo quidem distinguimus, intentionem scilicet ac opus; unam tamen bonitatem intentionis; veluti si dicamus bonum hominem, et filium boni hominis, duos quidem homines, non duas bonitates figuramus.
chunks.english: For, as blessed Augustine recalls, the very existence of evil is good, since God uses it well, nor does he permit it to exist otherwise, although the evil itself is by no means good. When therefore we say a man's intention is good and his work is good, we indeed distinguish two things, namely intention and work, yet only one goodness of intention. Just as if we say a good man and the son of a good man, we represent two men indeed, not two goodnesses.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut ergo homo bonus ex propria bonitate dicitur, filius autem boni hominis cum dicitur, nihil in se boni habere, ex hoc monstratur: ita cujusque intentio bona in se vocatur, opus vero bonum non ex se appellatur, quod ex bona procedat intentione. Una itaque est bonitas, unde tam intentio quam operatio bona dicitur, sicut una est bonitas, ex qua bonus homo et filius hominis boni, appellatur, vel una bonitas, ex qua bonus homo et bona hominis voluntas dicitur.
chunks.english: Just as therefore a good man is called good from his own goodness, but when the son of a good man is named, it is shown from this that he has no goodness in himself, so the intention of anyone is called good in itself, but a work is not called good from itself, because it proceeds from good intention. Therefore there is one goodness, from which both intention and operation are called good, just as there is one goodness from which both a good man and the son of a good man are named, or one goodness from which both a good man and the good will of a man are called.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ergo solent objicere operationem quoque intentionis remuneratione dignam esse, vel ad aliquod remunerationis augmentum proficere, attendant quod nugatoria eorum sit objectio. Duo, inquiunt, bona sunt intentio bona, et bonae intentionis effectus; et bonum bono adjunctum plus aliquid valere quam singula debet.
chunks.english: Those therefore who are accustomed to object that operation also is worthy of recompense of intention, or contributes to some increase of recompense, should note that their objection is trifling. They say: Two things are good, good intention and the effect of good intention, and good joined to good ought to be worth more than each singly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus respondeo, quod si ponamus plus illud totum valere quam singula; nunquid ideo majori remuneratione dignum cogimur concedere? Non utique. Multa quippe sunt tam animata quam inanimata, quorum multitudo ad plura utilis est, quam unumquodque in ea multitudine comprehensum, quibus tamen omnibus nulla prorsus remuneratio debetur. Ecce enim bos bovi vel equo adjunctus, sive lignum ligno, vel ferro, res quidem bonae sunt, et plus eorum multitudo, quam singula valet, cum tamen nihil omnino remunerationis amplius habeat.
chunks.english: To whom I respond that even if we suppose that whole to be worth more than the parts, are we therefore compelled to concede that it is worthy of greater recompense? Not at all. For there are many things, both animate and inanimate, whose multitude is useful for more things than any one thing included in that multitude, to all of which nevertheless no recompense at all is owed. Consider indeed that an ox joined to another ox or to a horse, or wood to wood, or to iron, these are indeed good things, and their multitude is worth more than each singly, yet it has absolutely nothing more of recompense.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Revera, inquies, ita est; quia non sunt talia, quae mereri possint, cum ratione careant. Sed nunquid opus nostrum rationem habet, ut mereri possit? Nequaquam, inquies; sed tamen mereri opus dicitur, quia nos mereri facit, hoc est dignos remuneratione, vel saltem majore. Sed hoc profecto supra negavimus, et cur negandum sit ea extra quae diximus, accipe.
chunks.english: Truly, you will say, it is so, because these are not things that can merit, since they lack reason. But does our work have reason so that it can merit? By no means, you will say. But yet a work is said to merit because it makes us merit, that is, worthy of recompense, or at least of greater recompense. But this we have certainly denied above, and hear why it should be denied apart from what we have said.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt duo in eodem proposito aedificandi domos pauperum, alter devotionis suae affectum implet, alter vero pecunia, quam praeparaverat, sibi violenter ablata, quod proposuit, consummare non permittitur, nulla sui culpa interveniente, sed sola eum violentia praepediente. Nunquid ejus meritum id quod exterius est actum minuere potuit apud Deum, aut malitia alterius eum minus acceptabilem Deo facere potuit, qui, quantumcunque potuit, pro Deo fecit?
chunks.english: There are two men with the same purpose of building houses for the poor. One fulfills his devotion's desire, but the other, when the money which he had prepared is violently taken from him, is not permitted to complete what he proposed, with no fault of his own intervening, but only violence preventing him. Could what was done externally diminish his merit before God, or could another's malice make him less acceptable to God, who did as much as he could for God?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: alioquin pecuniae magnitudo unumquemque meliorem ac digniorem facere posset, si videlicet ad meritum, vel augmentum meriti proficere ipsa posset, et quo ditiores homines essent, meliores fieri possent, cum ipsi ex copia divitiarum devotioni suae plus possent in operibus addere. Quod quidem existimare, ut opes scilicet ad veram beatitudinem, vel ad animae dignitatem quidquam valeant conferre, vel de meritis pauperum quidquam auferre, summa est insania. Si autem animam meliorem efficere non potest possessio rerum, utique nec eam Deo chariorem facere potest, nec in beatitudine meriti quidquam obtinere.
chunks.english: Otherwise the magnitude of money could make each person better and worthier, if indeed it could contribute to merit or to the increase of merit, and the richer men were, the better they could become, since they themselves from the abundance of riches could add more in works to their devotion. But to think this, namely that wealth can contribute anything to true blessedness or to the dignity of the soul, or take anything away from the merits of the poor, is the height of madness. But if the possession of things cannot make the soul better, certainly it cannot make it dearer to God, nor obtain anything in the blessedness of merit.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Recompense for External Works in This Life
chunks.latin: CAP. VIII. De remuneratione operum exteriorum.
chunks.english: Chapter Eight: On the Recompense of External Works

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec tamen negamus in hac vita bonis istis operibus vel malis aliquid tribui, ut ex praesenti retributione in praemio vel poena amplius ad bona incitemur, vel a malis retrahamur; et de aliis alii exempla sumant in faciendis quae conveniunt, vel cavendis, quae non conveniunt.
chunks.english: Yet we do not deny that in this life something is given to these good or evil works, so that from present retribution in reward or punishment we may be more strongly incited to good things or drawn back from evil things, and from others may others take examples in doing what is fitting or avoiding what is not fitting.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: That God and Man United in Christ Is Not Better Than God Alone
chunks.latin: CAP. IX. Quod Deus et homo in Christo uniti non sit melius aliquid quam solus Deus.
chunks.english: Chapter Nine: That God and Man United in Christ Is Not Something Better Than God Alone

chunks.speaker: narrator
