chunks.latin: Denique ut ad praemissa redeamus, ubi videlicet dictum est, quia bonum bono additum quiddam melius efficit quam unumquodque eorum per se sit; vide ne illuc usque ducaris, ut Christum, id est Deum et hominem sibi invicem in persona unitos melius quiddam dicas quam ipsa Christi divinitas vel humanitas sit, hoc est ipse Deus homini unitus vel ipse homo a Deo assumptus.
chunks.english: To return to what we said earlier, where we established that adding one good thing to another produces something better than either thing alone, be careful that you're not led to the conclusion that Christthat is, God and man united to each other in one personis somehow better than Christ's divinity or humanity itself. In other words, be careful not to say that God united to man, or man assumed by God, is something superior to God himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Constat quippe in Christo tam assumptum hominem, quam Deum assumentem esse bonum, et utramque substantiam non nisi bonam intelligi posse: sicut et in singulis hominibus tam corporea quam incorporea substantia bona est.
chunks.english: It's clear that in Christ, both the assumed man and the assuming God are good, and both substances can only be understood as good, just as in individual human beings both the bodily and incorporeal substances are good.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: licet ad dignitatem vel meritum animae bonitas corporis nihil referat. At vero quis totum id, quod Christus dicitur, hoc est simul Deum et hominem, vel quamcunque rerum multitudinem Deo praeferre audebit tanquam eo melius aliquid esse possit, qui et summum bonum est, et ab ipso quidquid boni habent, accipiunt omnia?
chunks.english: However, even though the goodness of the body contributes nothing to the dignity or merit of the soul, who would dare prefer the totality of what is called ChristGod and man togetheror any collection of things whatsoever, to God alone, as if anything could be better than him who is the supreme good and from whom all things receive whatever goodness they possess?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quamvis enim ad aliquid agendum nonnulla ita necessaria videantur, ut non id facere Deus sine illis possit, tanquam quibusdam adminiculis vel primordialibus causis, nihil tamen, quantacunque sit rerum magnitudo, Deo melius dici potest.
chunks.english: Although certain things may seem so necessary for accomplishing something that God couldn't do it without themas if they were supports or primary causesnevertheless, no matter how great the magnitude of these things, nothing can be said to be better than God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Etsi enim bonarum rerum numerus constat, ut bonitas in pluribus sit, non ideo bonitatem majorem esse contingit; veluti si scientia in pluribus abundet, aut scientiarum numerus crescat, non ideo scientiam cujusque crescere necesse est, ut major scilicet fiat quam prius.
chunks.english: For even though the number of good things increases so that goodness exists in more things, it doesn't follow that the goodness becomes greater. Similarly, if knowledge abounds in more people, or the number of branches of knowledge increases, it's not necessary that anyone's knowledge grows or becomes greater than before.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic et cum in se Deus bonus sit, et innumerabilia creet, quae nec esse, nec bona esse nisi per illum habent, bonitas per eum in pluribus est, ut major sit numerus bonarum rerum, nulla tamen bonitas ejus bonitati praeferri vel aequari potest.
chunks.english: In the same way, since God is good in himself and creates innumerable things that have neither being nor goodness except through him, goodness exists in more things through him so that the number of good things is greater, but no goodness can be preferred or equaled to his goodness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bonitas quidem in homine, et bonitas in Deo est, et cum diversae sint substantiae vel naturae quibus bonitas inest, nullius tamen rei bonitas divinae praeferri vel aequari potest; ac per hoc nihil melius, hoc est, majus bonum quam Deus, vel aeque bonum dicendum est.
chunks.english: Goodness exists in humans and goodness exists in God, and although the substances or natures in which goodness resides are different, nevertheless the goodness of no thing can be preferred or equaled to the divine. Therefore nothing should be called betterthat is, a greater goodthan God, or equally good.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Why Multiple Goods Don't Surpass a Single Good
chunks.latin: CAP. X. Quod multitudo bonorum non est melius uno bonorum.
chunks.english: Chapter Ten: Why Multiple Goods Don't Surpass a Single Good

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In opere vero et intentione nec bonitatum aut bonarum rerum numerus consistere videtur. Cum enim bona intentio, et bona operatio dicitur, hoc est, ex bona intentione procedens, sola bonitas intentionis designatur; nec in eadem significatione nomen boni retinetur, ut plura bona dicere possimus.
chunks.english: In action and intention, there doesn't appear to be a number of goodnesses or good things. For when we speak of a good intention and a good actionthat is, an action proceeding from good intentiononly the goodness of the intention is being designated. The word 'good' isn't being used in the same sense, so that we could speak of multiple goods.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam et cum dicimus simplicem hominem esse, et simplicem dictionem, non ideo haec esse concedimus plura simplicia, cum hoc nomen simplex aliter hic, et aliter ibi sumatur.
chunks.english: After all, when we say a person is simple and a statement is simple, we don't therefore admit that these are multiple simple things, since the word 'simple' is being used in one way here and another way there.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nemo ergo nos cogat, ut cum bonae intentioni bona operatio additur, (concedamus) bonum bono superaddi tanquam plura sint bona, pro quibus remuneratio crescere debeat; cum, ut dictum est, nec plura bona recte dicere possimus illa, quibus boni vocabulum nequaquam uno modo convenit.
chunks.english: Therefore no one should force us, when a good action is added to a good intention, to concede that one good is being added to another as if there were multiple goods for which the reward should increasesince, as we've said, we can't rightly speak of multiple goods when the term 'good' doesn't apply to them in the same way.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: How Good Intention Makes an Action Good
chunks.latin: CAP. XI. Quod intentione bona sit opus bonum.
chunks.english: Chapter Eleven: How Good Intention Makes an Action Good

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bonam quippe intentionem, hoc est, rectam in se dicimus; operationem vero, non quod boni aliquid in se suscipiat, sed quod ex bona intentione procedat.
chunks.english: We call an intention goodthat is, right in itselfbut we call an action good not because it receives something of goodness in itself, but because it proceeds from good intention.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et ab eodem homine cum in diversis temporibus idem fiat, pro diversitate tamen intentionis ejus operatio modo bona modo mala dicitur, et ita circa bonum et malum variari videtur.
chunks.english: That's why when the same person does the same thing at different times, the action is sometimes called good and sometimes bad depending on the diversity of his intention, and thus it seems to vary between good and evil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut haec propositio: Socrates sedet, vel ejus intellectus circa verum et falsum variatur, modo Socrate sedente, modo stante. Quam quidem permutationem varietatis circa verum et falsum ita in his Aristoteles contingere dicit, non quod ipsa, quae circa verum, vel falsum mutantur, aliquid suscipiant sui mutatione, sed quod res subjecta, id est Socrates, in se ipso moveatur, de sessione scilicet ad stationem, vel e converso.
chunks.english: It's similar to how this proposition'Socrates is sitting'or its meaning varies between true and false, depending on whether Socrates is sitting or standing. Aristotle says this change of variation between true and false happens in these cases not because the things that change with respect to truth or falsehood receive anything through their own change, but because the subject itselfthat is, Socratesmoves in himself from sitting to standing or vice versa.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: What Makes an Intention Truly Good
chunks.latin: CAP. XII. Unde bona intentio sit dicenda?
chunks.english: Chapter Twelve: What Makes an Intention Truly Good

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt autem qui bonam vel rectam intentionem esse arbitrantur, quotiescunque se aliquis bene agere credit, et Deo placere id, quod facit; sicut et illi qui martyres persequebantur, de quibus Veritas in Evangelio: Venit hora ut omnis qui interficit vos, arbitretur obsequium se praestare Deo.
chunks.english: There are some who think an intention is good or right whenever someone believes he's acting well and that what he's doing pleases God, just like those who persecuted the martyrs, about whom Truth says in the Gospel: 'The hour is coming when everyone who kills you will think he is offering service to God.' That's from the Gospel of John, chapter sixteen, verse two.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qualium ignorantiae Apostolus quidem compatiens ait: Testimonium illis perhibeo, quod aemulationem Dei habent, sed non secundum scientiam; hoc est, magnum fervorem habent ac desiderium in his faciendis, quae Deo placere credunt; sed quia in hoc animi sui zelo vel studio decipiuntur, erronea est eorum intentio, nec simplex est oculus cordis, ut clare videre queat, hoc est, ab errore sibi providere.
chunks.english: The Apostle, sympathizing with their ignorance, says: 'I bear witness that they have zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.' That's from Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter ten, verse two. In other words, they have great fervor and desire in doing what they believe pleases God, but because they're deceived in this zeal or eagerness of their soul, their intention is mistaken. The eye of the heart isn't simple enough to see clearlythat is, to guard itself from error.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Diligenter itaque Dominus, cum secundum intentionem rectam vel non rectam opera distingueret, oculum mentis, hoc est, intentionem, simplicem et quasi a sorde puram, ut clare videre possit, aut e contrario tenebrosam vocavit cum diceret: Si oculus tuus simplex fuerit, totum corpus tuum lucidum erit; hoc est si intentio recta fuerit, tota massa operum inde provenientium, quae more corporalium rerum videri possit, erit luce digna, hoc est bona; sic e contrario.
chunks.english: Therefore the Lord, when distinguishing works according to right or wrong intention, carefully called the eye of the mindthat is, the intentioneither simple and as it were pure from filth so that it can see clearly, or conversely dark, when he said: 'If your eye is simple, your whole body will be full of light.' This means if your intention is right, the entire mass of works proceeding from it, which can be seen like bodily things, will be worthy of lightthat is, good. And conversely the opposite.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non est itaque intentio bona dicenda, quia bona videtur, sed insuper quia talis est, sicut existimatur; cum videlicet illud, ad quod tendit, si Deo placere credit, in hac insuper existimatione sua nequaquam fallatur.
chunks.english: Therefore an intention shouldn't be called good just because it seems good, but moreover because it actually is what it's believed to benamely, when what it aims at, if it believes it pleases God, isn't mistaken in this belief.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Alioquin ipsi etiam infideles sicut et nos bona opera haberent, cum ipsi etiam non minus quam nos per opera sua se salvari, vel Deo placere credant.
chunks.english: Otherwise even unbelievers would have good works just like us, since they too believe no less than we do that they're saved through their works or that they please God.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Sin Exists Only Against Conscience
chunks.latin: CAP. XIII. Quod peccatum non est nisi contra conscientiam.
chunks.english: Chapter Thirteen: Sin Exists Only Against Conscience

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quis tamen quaerat utrum illi martyrum vel Christi persecutores in eo peccarent, quod placere Deo credebant; aut illud sine peccato dimittere possent quod nullatenus esse dimittendum censebant, profecto secundum hoc, quod superius peccatum esse descripsimus contemptum Dei, vel consentire in eo, in quod credit consentiendum non esse, non possumus dicere eos in hoc peccasse, nec ignorantiam cujusquam, vel ipsam etiam infidelitatem, cum qua nemo salvari potest, peccatum esse.
chunks.english: Yet if someone asks whether those persecutors of the martyrs or of Christ sinned in believing they were pleasing God, or whether they could have abandoned what they did without sin when they thought it should absolutely not be abandonedwell, according to what we described earlier as sin, namely contempt for God or consenting to what one believes should not be consented to, we can't say they sinned in this. Nor can we say that anyone's ignorance, or even unbelief itself, with which no one can be saved, is sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui enim Christum ignorant, et ob hoc fidem Christianam respuunt, quia eam Deo contrariam credunt, quem in hoc Dei contemptum habent quod propter Deum faciunt, et ob hoc bene se facere arbitrantur, praesertim cum Apostolus dicat: Si cor nostrum non reprehenderit nos, fiduciam habemus apud Deum: tanquam si diceret, ubi contra conscientiam nostram non praesumimus, frustra nos apud Deum de culpa reos statui formidamus?
chunks.english: For those who don't know Christ and therefore reject the Christian faith because they believe it's contrary to Godwhat contempt of God do they have when they do this for God's sake and therefore think they're acting rightly, especially when the Apostle says: 'If our heart doesn't condemn us, we have confidence before God.' That's from John's first letter, chapter three, verse twenty-one. It's as if he's saying: when we don't presume against our conscience, we needlessly fear being held guilty of fault before God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aut si talium ignorantia peccato minime est ascribenda, quomodo ipse Dominus pro crucifigentibus se orat dicens: Pater, dimitte illis; non enim sciunt quid faciunt; vel Stephanus, hoc instructus exemplo, pro lapidantibus supplicans ait: Domine, ne statuas illis hoc peccatum?
chunks.english: Or if the ignorance of such people shouldn't be attributed to sin at all, why does the Lord himself pray for those crucifying him, saying: 'Father, forgive them, for they don't know what they're doing'? That's from the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-three, verse thirty-four. And why does Stephen, instructed by this example, pray for those stoning him: 'Lord, don't hold this sin against them'? That's from the Acts of the Apostles, chapter seven, verse fifty-nine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim ignoscendum videtur ubi culpa non praecessit, nec aliud solet dici ignosci, nisi poenam condonari quam culpa meruit. Stephanus insuper peccatum patenter appellat, quod de ignorantia erat.
chunks.english: For there seems to be nothing to forgive where no guilt preceded, nor is the word 'forgive' usually used except to mean pardoning the punishment that guilt deserved. Moreover, Stephen openly calls it a sin, though it came from ignorance.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Various Meanings of Sin
chunks.latin: CAP. XIV. Quot modis peccatum dicatur?
chunks.english: Chapter Fourteen: The Various Meanings of Sin

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ut objectis plenius respondeamus, sciendum est nomen peccati diversis modis accipi; proprie tamen peccatum dicitur ipse Dei contemptus, vel consensus in malum, ut supra meminimus. A quo parvuli sunt immunes, et naturaliter stulti: qui, cum merita non habeant tanquam ratione carentes, nihil eis ad peccatum imputatur, et solummodo per sacramenta salvantur.
chunks.english: But to respond more fully to these objections, we should understand that the word 'sin' is used in various ways. Properly speaking, though, sin means contempt of God itself, or consent to evil, as we mentioned above. From this, small children and the naturally simple-minded are immune. Since they have no merit because they lack reason, nothing is imputed to them as sin, and they're saved only through the sacraments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicitur etiam peccatum hostia pro peccato, secundum quod Apostolus Dominum Jesum Christum dicit factum esse peccatum. Poena etiam peccati dicitur peccatum sive maledictum, juxta quod dicimus peccatum dimitti, hoc est, poenam condonari, et Dominum Jesum Christum portasse peccata nostra, hoc est, poenam peccatorum nostrorum, vel ex eis provenientes sustinuisse.
chunks.english: Sin is also called the sacrifice for sin, according to which the Apostle says the Lord Jesus Christ was made sin. The punishment of sin is also called sin or curse, in the sense that we say sin is forgiventhat is, punishment is pardonedand that the Lord Jesus Christ bore our sins, meaning he sustained the punishment of our sins or what proceeded from them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed cum parvulos originale peccatum dicimus habere, vel nos omnes secundum Apostolum in Adam peccasse, tale est, ac si diceretur a peccato illius originem nostrae poenae vel damnationis sententiam incurrisse.
chunks.english: But when we say little children have original sin, or that we all sinned in Adam according to the Apostle, it's as if we're saying we incurred from his sin the origin of our punishment or the sentence of condemnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Opera quoque ipsa peccati, vel quidquid non recte scimus, aut volumus, nonnunquam peccata dicimus. Quid est enim aliquem fecisse peccatum, nisi peccati implesse effectum?
chunks.english: We also sometimes call the very works of sin, or whatever we don't rightly know or will, sins. For what does it mean to have committed a sin, except to have carried out the effect of sin?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec mirum, cum e converso ipsa peccata vocemus facta juxta illud Athanasii: Et reddituri sunt, inquit, de factis propriis rationem, et qui bona egerunt, ibunt in vitam aeternam; qui vero mala, in ignem aeternum.
chunks.english: This isn't surprising, since conversely we call sins themselves deeds, according to Athanasius who says: 'They will give account of their own deeds, and those who did good will go into eternal life, but those who did evil into eternal fire.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est enim de factis propriis? an tanquam de his tantum, quae opere impleverunt, faciendum sit judicium, ut plus accipiat in remuneratione, qui plus habuerit in opere? Vel a damnatione sit immunis, qui in eo, quod intendit, effectu caruit, sicut ipse diabolus, qui, quod praesumpsit affectu, non obtinuit effectu? Absit!
chunks.english: For what does 'of their own deeds' mean? Is judgment to be made only on what they accomplished in action, so that whoever had more in action receives more in reward? Or is someone immune from damnation who lacked the outcome of what he intended, like the devil himself, who didn't obtain in outcome what he presumed in desire? Absolutely not!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De factis itaque propriis dicit de consensu eorum, quae implere decreverunt, hoc est, de peccatis, quae apud Dominum pro opere facti deputantur; cum ille scilicet sic puniat illa, sicuti nos opera.
chunks.english: Therefore when it speaks of their own deeds, it means their consent to what they decided to accomplishthat is, their sins, which before the Lord are counted as accomplished deeds, since he punishes them just as we do actions.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum autem Stephanus peccatum dicit, quod per ignorantiam in ipsum committebant Judaei poenam ipsam, quam patiebatur ex peccato primorum parentum, sicut et caeteras provenientes, vel injustam eorum actionem, quam habebant in lapidando, peccatum dixit.
chunks.english: Now when Stephen speaks of the sin that the Jews were committing against him through ignorance, he called it sin meaning either the very punishment he was suffering from the sin of the first parents, along with the other punishments that proceed from it, or their unjust action in stoning him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod quidem rogabat, eis non statui, hoc est, propter hoc eos nec corporaliter puniri. Saepe etenim Deus aliquos hic corporaliter punit, nulla eorum culpa hoc exigente, nec tamen sine causa, veluti cum justis etiam afflictiones immittit ad aliquam eorum purgationem, vel probationem: vel aliquos cum affligi permittit, ut postmodum hinc liberentur, et ex collato beneficio glorificetur, sicut in illo caeco actum est, de quo ipse ait: Neque hic peccavit, neque parentes ejus, ut caecus nasceretur, sed ut manifestentur opera Dei in illo.
chunks.english: He was praying that this not be held against themthat is, that they not be bodily punished for it. For God often punishes some people bodily here, though no guilt of theirs demands it, yet not without cause. For instance, he sends afflictions even upon the just for their purification or testing, or permits some to be afflicted so that they may later be freed from this and God may be glorified through the benefit conferred, as happened with that blind man about whom he said: 'Neither this man sinned nor his parents, that he should be born blind, but that the works of God might be manifested in him.' That's from the Gospel of John, chapter nine, verse three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis etiam neget quandoque cum malis parentibus pro culpa eorum innocentes filios periclitari, vel affligi, sicut in Sodomis factum est, vel in multis populis saepe contingit, ut quo poena magis extenditur, amplius mali terreantur?
chunks.english: Who would also deny that sometimes innocent children are endangered or afflicted along with evil parents because of their guilt, as happened in Sodom or as often happens in many peoples, so that the more widely punishment extends, the more evil people are terrified?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod diligenter beatus Stephanus attendens peccatum, hoc est, poenam, quam tolerabat a Judaeis, vel id quod non recte agebant, orabat eis non statui, hoc est, propter hoc nec corporaliter puniri.
chunks.english: Carefully considering this, blessed Stephen prayed that the sinthat is, the punishment he was enduring from the Jews, or what they were doing incorrectlynot be held against them, meaning that they not be bodily punished for it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In hac quoque sententia Dominus fuerat, cum dicebat: Pater, dimitte illis, id est, ne vindices id quod agunt in me, vel corporali poena: quod quidem fieri rationabiliter posset, si nulla etiam culpa eorum praecessisset, ut caeteri scilicet hoc videntes vel ipsi etiam recognoscerent ex poena se non recte in hoc egisse.
chunks.english: The Lord held this same view when he said: 'Father, forgive them'that is, don't avenge what they're doing to me, even with bodily punishment. This could reasonably happen even if no guilt of theirs had preceded, so that others seeing it, or they themselves, might recognize from the punishment that they hadn't acted rightly in this.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At vero Dominum decebat hoc suae orationis exemplo nos maxime ad patientiae virtutem et ad summae dilectionis exhibitionem exhortari, ut quod ipse docuerat verbis nos, videlicet pro inimicis quoque orare, proprio exemplo nobis exhiberet in opere.
chunks.english: But it was fitting for the Lord to use this example of his own prayer to urge us especially toward the virtue of patience and the demonstration of supreme love, so that what he had taught us in wordsnamely, to pray even for enemieshe would show us in action through his own example.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod ergo dixit: dimitte, non ad culpam praecedentem, vel contemptum Dei, quem hic haberent, respexit, sed ad rationem inferendae poenae, quae non sine causa, ut diximus, subsequi posset, quamvis culpa non praecessisset; sicut in propheta contigit, qui, contra Samariam missus, comedendo egit, quod Dominus prohibuerat; in quo tamen cum nihil per Dei contemptum praesumeret, sed per alium prophetam deceptus, non tam ex reatu culpae quam ex operis perpetratione innocentia ejus mortem incurrit.
chunks.english: Therefore when he said 'forgive,' he wasn't looking at preceding guilt or contempt of God that they might have had, but at the rationale for inflicting punishment, which could reasonably follow, as we said, even if no guilt had precededjust as happened with the prophet who was sent to Samaria and ate in violation of what the Lord had forbidden. Yet since he presumed nothing through contempt of God but was deceived by another prophet, his innocence incurred death not so much from the charge of guilt as from the carrying out of the deed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus quippe, ut beatus meminit Gregorius, nonnunquam sententiam mutat, consilium vero nunquam; hoc est, quod praecipere vel comminari aliqua de causa decrevit, saepe id non implere disponit. Consilium vero ejus fixum permanet, hoc est, quod in praescientia sua disponit, ut faciat, nunquam efficacia caret.
chunks.english: For God, as blessed Gregory remembers, sometimes changes his sentence but never his counsel. That is, what he decided to command or threaten for some reason, he often arranges not to fulfill. But his counsel remains fixedthat is, what he arranges in his foreknowledge to do never lacks effectiveness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut ergo in Abraham praeceptum de immolatione filii, vel comminationem in Ninivitis factam non tenuit, et sic, ut diximus, sententiam mutavit: ita praedictus propheta, cui prohibuerat comedere in via, mutari ejus sententiam credidit, et se maxime delinquere, si alium prophetam non audiret, qui se ad hoc a Domino mitti asserebat, ut ejus lassitudinem reficeret cibo.
chunks.english: Therefore just as he didn't keep the command about sacrificing his son in Abraham's case, or the threat made against the Ninevites, and thus changed his sentence as we said, so the aforementioned prophet, to whom he had forbidden eating on the journey, believed his sentence was being changed and that he would be greatly at fault if he didn't listen to another prophet who claimed he was sent by the Lord to refresh his weariness with food.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Absque culpa igitur hoc fecit, in quo culpam vitare decrevit, nec ei mors repentina nocuit, quem ab aerumnis vitae praesentis liberavit, et multis ad providentiam profuit, cum justum sic videant sine culpa puniri, et illud in eo impleri quod alibi Domino dicitur: Tu Deus, eum justus sis, juste omnia disponis, cum eum quoque, qui non debet puniri, condemnes.
chunks.english: Therefore he did this without guilt, having decided to avoid guilt in it, nor did sudden death harm him since it freed him from the hardships of the present life. It benefited many for their understanding of providence when they saw a just man punished without guilt, and saw fulfilled in him what is said elsewhere to the Lord: 'O God, since you are just, you arrange all things justly, even when you condemn one who should not be punished.' That's loosely from the book of Wisdom, chapter twelve, verse fifteen.
chunks.notes: The author's citation is imprecise; he blends the sense rather than quoting exactly

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Condemnas, inquit, ad mortem non aeternam, sed corporalem. Sicut enim sine meritis nonnulli salvantur, ut parvuli, et sola gratia vitam assequuntur aeternam: ita non absurdum est nonnullos poenas corporales sustinere, quas non meruerunt, sicut et de parvulis constat sine baptismi gratia defunctis, qui tam corporali, quam aeterna morte damnantur, et multi etiam innocentes affliguntur.
chunks.english: You condemn, he says, to deathnot eternal but bodily. For just as some are saved without merits, like small children, and attain eternal life by grace alone, so it's not absurd that some endure bodily punishments they didn't deserve, just as is clear about little children who die without the grace of baptism, who are condemned to both bodily and eternal death, and many innocent people are also afflicted.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid itaque mirum, si crucifigentes Dominum ex illa injusta actione, quamvis eos ignorantia excusat a culpa, poenam, ut diximus temporalem non irrationabiliter incurrere possent, atque ideo dictum est: dimitte illis, hoc est poenam quam hinc, ut diximus, non irrationabiliter incurrere possent, ne inferas?
chunks.english: What then is surprising if those crucifying the Lord, from that unjust action, though ignorance excuses them from guilt, could not unreasonably incur temporal punishment as we said, and therefore it was said: 'forgive them'that is, don't inflict the punishment they could not unreasonably incur from this, as we said?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut autem, quod isti per ignorantiam egerunt, vel ipsa etiam ignorantia peccatum proprie, hoc est, contemptus Dei, non dicitur: ita nec infidelitas, quamvis ipsa necessario aeternae vitae aditum adultis ratione jam utentibus intercludat.
chunks.english: Now just as what these people did through ignorance, or the ignorance itself, isn't properly called sinthat is, contempt of Godso neither is unbelief, even though it necessarily blocks access to eternal life for adults already using reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad damnationem quippe sufficit Evangelio non credere, Christum ignorare, sacramenta Ecclesiae non suscipere, quamvis hoc non (tam) per malitiam, quam per ignorantiam fiat. De qualibus et Veritas ait: Qui non credit, jam judicatus est. Et Apostolus: Et qui ignorat, inquit, ignorabitur.
chunks.english: For damnation it's sufficient not to believe the Gospel, to be ignorant of Christ, not to receive the sacraments of the Church, even if this happens not so much through malice as through ignorance. About such people Truth also says: 'Whoever doesn't believe is already judged.' That's from the Gospel of John, chapter three, verse eighteen. And the Apostle says: 'And whoever is ignorant will be ignored.' That's from Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter fourteen, verse thirty-eight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum autem dicimus ignoranter nos peccare, hoc est, tale quid, quod non convenit facere, peccare non in contemptu, sed in operatione sumimus. Nam et philosophi peccare dicunt inconvenienter aliquid seu dicere, quamvis illud nihil ad offensam Dei videatur pertinere.
chunks.english: But when we say we sin ignorantly, we're using 'sin' to mean doing something that shouldn't be done, not in terms of contempt but in terms of action. For even philosophers say that saying or doing something inappropriately is sinning, even though it seems to have nothing to do with offending God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde Aristoteles in ad aliquid cum de vitiosa relativorum assignatione loqueretur, ait: At vero aliquoties non videbitur converti, nisi convenienter, ad quod dicitur, assignetur. Si enim peccet is, qui assignat, ut ala si assignetur avis, non convertitur, ut sit avis alae.
chunks.english: Hence Aristotle, in his discussion of relations when speaking about the faulty assignment of relatives, says: 'But sometimes it won't seem to convert unless what it's said in relation to is appropriately assigned. For if the one making the assignment makes a mistakefor instance, if wing is assigned to birdit doesn't convert, so that bird would be of wing.'
chunks.notes: Aristotle's Categories, discussing proper logical relations

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo isto modo peccatum dicamus, omne quod vitiose agimus, vel contra salutem nostram habemus, utique et infidelitas, et ignorantia eorum, quae ad salutem credi necesse est, peccata dicemus, quamvis ibi nullus Dei contemptus videatur.
chunks.english: Therefore if we use the word 'sin' in this way for everything we do wrongly or have against our salvation, then certainly both unbelief and ignorance of what must be believed for salvation we'll call sins, even though no contempt of God appears there.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Proprie tamen peccatum illud dici arbitror, quod nusquam sine culpa contingere potest. Ignorare vero Deum, vel non ei credere, vel opera ipsa, quae non recte fiunt, multis sine culpa possunt accidere.
chunks.english: Yet I think sin is properly said to be what can never happen without guilt. But being ignorant of God, or not believing in him, or the very actions that are done incorrectlythese can happen to many without guilt.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quis enim Evangelio vel Christo non credit, quia praedicatio ad ipsum non pervenerit, juxta illud Apostoli: Quomodo credent ei, quem non audierunt? quomodo autem audient sine praedicante?
chunks.english: For if someone doesn't believe in the Gospel or in Christ because the preaching hasn't reached him, according to the Apostle's words: 'How will they believe in him whom they haven't heard? But how will they hear without a preacher?' That's from Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter ten, verse fourteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae hinc ei culpa potest assignari, quod non credit? Non credebat Cornelius in Christum, donec Petrus ad eum missus de hoc ipsum instruxit, qui quamvis antea lege naturali Deum recognosceret atque diligeret, ex quo meruit de oratione sua exaudiri, et Deo acceptas eleemosynas habere, tamen si eum ante fidem Christi de hac luce migrasse contingeret, nequaquam ei vitam promittere auderemus, quantumcunque bona opera ejus viderentur, nec eum fidelibus, sed magis infidelibus conumeraremus, quantocunque studio salutis esset occupatus.
chunks.english: What guilt from this can be assigned to him for not believing? Cornelius didn't believe in Christ until Peter was sent to him and instructed him about this. Although he previously recognized and loved God by natural law, for which he merited having his prayer heard and his alms accepted by God, nevertheless if he had departed from this life before faith in Christ, we wouldn't dare promise him life, however good his works appeared, nor would we count him among believers but rather among unbelievers, however occupied he was with concern for salvation.
chunks.notes: Reference to Acts chapter 10

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Abyssus quippe multa Dei judicia sunt, qui nonnunquam reluctantes, vel minus de salute sua sollicitos trahit, et se offerentes, vel ad credendum paratiores profundissimo dispensationis suae consilio respuit.
chunks.english: For God's judgments are a deep abyss. Sometimes he draws those who resist or are less concerned about their salvation, and by the most profound counsel of his dispensation he rejects those who offer themselves or are more ready to believe.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic enim illum se offerentem: Magister, sequar te quocunque ieris, reprobavit. Et alterum excusantem se per sollicitudinem, quam habuit de patre, nec ad horam in hac pietatis excusatione toleravit.
chunks.english: For he rejected the one who offered himself, saying: 'Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go.' That's from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eight, verse nineteen. And another who excused himself through concern he had for his father, he didn't tolerate even for an hour in this excuse of piety.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Denique et quarumdam civitatum obstinationem increpans ait: Vae tibi, Corozain; vae tibi, Bethsaida, quia si in Tyro et Sidone virtutes factae fuissent, quae factae sunt in vobis, jam olim in cilicio et cinere poenitentiam egissent.
chunks.english: Finally, reproaching the obstinacy of certain cities, he said: 'Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.' That's from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eleven, verse twenty-one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce illis obtulit non solum praedicationem suam, verum etiam miraculorum exhibitionem, quas tamen prius noverat non esse credituras. Has vero gentilium alias civitates, quas ad fidem suscipiendam faciles esse non ignorabat, sua tunc visitatione non censuit dignas, in quibus quidem, cum aliqui subtracto sibi praedicationis verbo, tamen ad suscipiendum ipsum parati, perierunt, quis hoc eorum imputet culpae, quod nulla negligentia videmus accidere?
chunks.english: Look, he offered them not only his preaching but also the display of miracles, yet he already knew they wouldn't believe. But those other cities of the Gentiles, which he knew would be ready to receive the faith, he didn't consider worthy of his visitation at that time. In them, when some people perished though they were ready to receive him but the word of preaching was withheld from themwho would impute this to their guilt, when we see it happened through no negligence of theirs?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et tamen hanc eorum infidelitatem, in qua defuncti sunt, ad damnationem sufficere dicimus, quamvis hujus caecitatis, in qua Dominus eos dimiserit, causa minus nobis appareat.
chunks.english: And yet we say their unbelief, in which they died, is sufficient for damnation, though the reason for this blindness in which the Lord left them is less apparent to us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam profecto, si quis peccato eorum sine culpa ascribat, fortassis licebit, cum absurdum ei videatur, tales sine peccato damnari?
chunks.english: If someone attributes this to their sin without guilt, perhaps that will be permissible, since it seems absurd to him that such people should be damned without sin?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nos tamen proprie peccatum, ut saepe jam meminimus, illud solum dici arbitramur, quod in culpa negligentiae consistit, nec in aliquibus esse potest, cujuscunque sint aetatis, quin ex hoc damnari mereantur.
chunks.english: Yet we think that sin, properly speaking, as we've often mentioned, is only what consists in the guilt of negligence, and it can't exist in anyone of any age without their deserving to be damned because of it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non credere vero Christum, quod infidelitatis est, quomodo parvulis, vel his quibus non est annuntiatum, culpae debeat ascribi, non video, vel quidquid per ignorantiam invincibilem fit, cui vel praevidere non valuimus; veluti si quis forte hominem, quem non videt in silva sagitta interficiat, dum feris vel avibus sagittandis intendit.
chunks.english: But I don't see how not believing in Christwhich is unbeliefshould be attributed to guilt for small children or for those to whom it hasn't been announced, or for whatever happens through invincible ignorance that we couldn't foresee. For instance, if someone happens to kill with an arrow a person he doesn't see in the forest while intent on shooting wild beasts or birds.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quem tamen dum peccare per ignorantiam dicimus, sicut nos quandoque fatemur non solum in consensu, verum etiam in cogitatione peccare, hoc loco non proprie pro culpa ponimus, sed large accipimus, pro eo scilicet, quod nos facere minime convenit, sive id per errorem sive per negligentiam, vel quocunque modo inconvenienti fiat.
chunks.english: Yet when we say such a person sins through ignorance, just as we sometimes admit that we sin not only in consent but also in thought, in this context we're not using the word properly to mean guilt but taking it broadly to mean what it's entirely unfitting for us to do, whether it happens through error or negligence or in any inappropriate way.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tale est ergo per ignorantiam peccare, non culpam in hoc habere, sed quod nobis non convenit, facere, vel peccare in cogitatione, hoc est, voluntate, quod nos velle minime convenit, vel in locutione, aut in operatione, loqui nos vel agere, quod non oportet, etsi per ignorantiam nobis invitis illud eveniat.
chunks.english: Therefore to sin through ignorance is like this: not to have guilt in it, but to do what isn't fitting for us. Or to sin in thoughtthat is, in willto will what it's entirely unfitting for us to will. Or in speech or action, to speak or act in a way we shouldn't, even if it happens against our will through ignorance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic et illos, si persequebantur Christum vel suos, quos persequendos credebant per operationem peccasse dicimus, qui tamen gravius culpam peccassent, si contra conscientiam eis parcerent.
chunks.english: In this way we say that those who persecuted Christ or his followers, whom they believed should be persecuted, sinned through their action, yet they would have sinned more gravely in guilt if they had spared them against their conscience.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Whether All Sin Is Forbidden
chunks.latin: CAP. XV. Utrum omne peccatum sit interdictum?
chunks.english: Chapter Fifteen: Whether All Sin Is Forbidden

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quaeritur autem utrum omne peccatum Deus nobis interdicat? Quod si recipiamus, videtur hoc irrationabiliter agere, cum nequaquam vita ista sine peccatis saltem venialibus transigi possit.
chunks.english: The question is raised whether God forbids us every sin. If we accept this, he seems to be acting irrationally, since this life can't possibly be lived without at least venial sins.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim omnia nos cavere peccata praecepit, nos autem omnia cavere non possumus, utique nequaquam, sicut ipse promisit jugum suave nobis, vel onus leve imponit, sed quod longe vires transcendens nostras minime portare valemus, sicut et de jugo legis Petrus apostolus profitetur.
chunks.english: For if he commanded us to avoid all sins, but we can't avoid them all, then he's certainly not imposing on us a sweet yoke or light burden as he promised, but one that far exceeds our strength and that we can't possibly bear, just as Peter the apostle declares about the yoke of the law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis enim a verbo saltem otioso semper sibi praevidere potest, ut in eo nunquam excedens perfectionem illam teneat, de qua Jacobus ait: Si quis in verbo non offendit, hic perfectus est vir? qui etiam cum praemisisset: in multis offendimus omnes; et alius magnae dicat perfectionis apostolus: Si dixerimus, quia peccatum non habemus, nos ipsos seducimus, et veritas in nobis non est, quam difficile, imo impossibile nostrae infirmitati videatur, immunes omnino a peccato manere, neminem latere reor.
chunks.english: For who can always guard himself from even an idle word, so as never to fail in holding that perfection about which James says: 'If anyone doesn't offend in word, he's a perfect man'? That's from the letter of James, chapter three, verse two. He also prefaced it by saying: 'We all offend in many things.' And another apostle of great perfection says: 'If we say we have no sin, we deceive ourselves and the truth isn't in us.' That's from John's first letter, chapter one, verse eight. I think everyone knows how difficult, indeed impossible, it seems for our weakness to remain entirely immune from sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ita, inquam, si peccati vocabulum large, ut diximus, accipientes illa etiam vocemus peccata, quaecunque non convenienter facimus. Si autem proprie peccatum intelligentes solum Dei contemptum dicamus peccatum, potest revera sine hoc vita ista transigi, quamvis cum maxima difficultate.
chunks.english: So, I say, if we take the word 'sin' broadly as we said, and also call sins whatever we do inappropriately, then this is true. But if understanding sin properly we call only contempt of God sin, then this life can truly be lived without it, though with the greatest difficulty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec profecto illud, ut supra meminimus, nobis a Deo prohibitum est, nisi consensus mali, quo Deum contemnimus, etiam cum de opere praeceptio fieri videtur, sicut superius exposuimus, ubi etiam ostendimus aliter nequaquam a nobis praecepta posse sua custodiri.
chunks.english: And certainly, as we mentioned above, what is forbidden us by God is nothing other than consent to evil, by which we despise God, even when the command seems to concern action, as we explained earlier, where we also showed that his commands can't be kept by us in any other way.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Peccatorum autem alia venialia dicuntur, et quasi levia, alia damnabilia sive gravia. Rursus damnabilium quaedam criminalia dicuntur, quae in illis personam infamem vel criminosam facere habent, si in audientiam veniant, quaedam vero minime.
chunks.english: Now among sins, some are called venial and as it were light, others damnable or grave. Again, among damnable sins some are called criminal, which make the person infamous or criminal if they come to public hearing, while others don't.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Venialia quidem, vel talia peccata sunt, quando in eo consentimus, cui non consentiendum esse scimus, sed tunc tamen non occurrit memoriae illud quod scimus; multa quippe scimus, etiam dormientes, vel quando eorum non recordamur.
chunks.english: Venial sins, or sins of this kind, occur when we consent to what we know shouldn't be consented to, but at that moment what we know doesn't come to mind. For we know many things even while sleeping, or when we don't remember them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim dormiendo nostras amittimus scientias, vel stulti efficimur, aut cum vigilamus, sapientes efficimur. Quandoque itaque vel in vaniloquium, vel in superfluum esum vel potum consentimus, quod tamen nequaquam esse faciendum scimus; sed tunc minime recordabamur, quod non esset faciendum.
chunks.english: For we don't lose our knowledge by sleeping, or become foolish, nor do we become wise when we wake. Therefore sometimes we consent to idle talk or to excessive eating or drinking, though we know this absolutely shouldn't be done, but at the time we didn't at all remember that it shouldn't be done.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tales itaque consensus, quos per oblivionem incurrimus, venialia aut levia dicuntur peccata, hoc est, non magnae satisfactionis poena corrigenda, ut vel extra ecclesiam positi, vel gravi abstinentia pressi ob talia plectamur; pro quibus quidem negligentiis poenitentibus dimittendis verba quotidianae confessionis frequentamus, in qua minime commemoratio graviorum culparum facienda est, sed tantum leviorum.
chunks.english: Therefore such acts of consent that we incur through forgetfulness are called venial or light sinsthat is, not to be corrected by the punishment of great satisfaction, so that we'd be placed outside the church or pressed by severe abstinence on account of such things. For these negligences, to be forgiven to penitents, we practice the words of daily confession, in which mention of graver faults should absolutely not be made, but only of lighter ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Neque enim ibi dicere debemus, peccavi in perjurio, in homicidio, in adulterio, et consimilibus, quae damnabilia, et graviora dicuntur peccata; haec quippe non per oblivionem, sicut illa incurrimus, sed tanquam ex studio, et deliberatione committimus, abominabiles etiam Deo effecti juxta illud Psalmistae: Abominabiles facti sunt in studiis suis: quasi exsecrabiles, et valde odibiles ex his in quibus scienter praesumpserunt.
chunks.english: For we shouldn't say there: I have sinned in perjury, in murder, in adultery, and similar things, which are called damnable and graver sins. For we don't incur these through forgetfulness like the others, but rather commit them as if from deliberation and intention, even becoming abominable to God according to the Psalmist's words: 'They have become abominable in their pursuits.' From Psalm fourteen, verse one. That is, execrable and very hateful because of what they knowingly presumed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Horum autem alia criminalia dicuntur, quae per effectum cognita naevo magnae culpae hominem detrahunt, ut consensus perjurii, homicidii, adulterii, quae plurimum Ecclesiam scandalizant.
chunks.english: Among these, some are called criminal, which when known through their effect detract from a person with the stain of great guilt, such as consent to perjury, murder, or adultery, which greatly scandalize the Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum vero supra quam necesse est, cibo indulgemus vel non mediocri cultu ex vana gloria nos adornamus, etsi hoc scienter praesumimus, non haec crimini ascribuntur, et apud multos plus laudis habent, quam vituperationis.
chunks.english: But when we indulge in food more than necessary, or adorn ourselves with considerable finery from vainglory, even if we knowingly presume this, these things aren't attributed to crime and among many people have more praise than blame.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Whether Avoiding Light Sins Is Better Than Avoiding Grave Ones
chunks.latin: CAP. XVI. Utrum melius sit a levioribus culpis, quam gravioribus abstinere?
chunks.english: Chapter Sixteen: Whether Avoiding Light Sins Is Better Than Avoiding Grave Ones

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt, qui perfectius, et ideo melius dicunt providere a venialibus peccatis quam a criminalibus, eo quod difficilius id videatur, et majoris studii sollicitudine indigeat.
chunks.english: There are those who say it's more perfect, and therefore better, to guard against venial sins than against criminal ones, because it seems more difficult and requires greater concern and effort.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus primum illud respondeo Tullianum: Quod si laboriosum, non ideo gloriosum. Alioquin majoris meriti apud Dominum essent, qui grave jugum legis portaverunt, quam qui evangelica libertate deserviunt: quia timor poenam habet, quam perfecta charitas foras mittit, et quicunque timore aguntur, plus opere laborant, quam quos charitas spontaneos facit.
chunks.english: To them I first respond with that saying of Cicero: 'Just because something is laborious doesn't make it glorious.' Otherwise those who bore the heavy yoke of the law would have greater merit before the Lord than those who serve in evangelical freedom, because fear involves punishment, which perfect love casts out, and whoever are driven by fear labor more in their work than those whom love makes willing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde laborantes et oneratos ad suave jugum, et onus leve sumendum Dominus exhortatur, ut videlicet de servitute legis, qua premebantur, ad libertatem transeant Evangelii, et qui a timore incoeperant, charitate consummentur, quae sine difficultate omnia suffert, omnia sustinet: nihil quippe amanti difficile, maxime cum non carnalis, sed spiritualis amor Dei tanto est fortior, quanto verior.
chunks.english: Hence the Lord urges those laboring and burdened to take up the sweet yoke and light burden, so that they may pass from the servitude of the law, by which they were oppressed, to the freedom of the Gospel, and those who began from fear may be perfected by love, which without difficulty bears all things, endures all things. For nothing is difficult to one who loves, especially since spiritual love of God, not carnal, is stronger the truer it is.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis etiam nesciat difficilius nobis provideri a pulice, quam ab hoste; vel ab offendiculo parvi lapidis, quam magni? Sed nunquid ideo id cavere quod difficilius est, melius aut salubrius judicamus? Non utique. Quare? quia quod difficilius est, cavere, minus potest nocere.
chunks.english: Who doesn't know that it's more difficult for us to guard against a flea than an enemy, or against stumbling over a small stone than a large one? But do we therefore judge that avoiding what's more difficult is better or healthier? Certainly not. Why? Because what's more difficult to avoid can harm us less.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic ergo, etsi ponamus difficilius a venialibus peccatis quam a criminalibus providere, plus tamen hoc vitari quam quae periculosiora sunt, convenit, et quae majorem merentur poenam, et quibus amplius offendi credimus Deum, et magis ei ea displicere.
chunks.english: Therefore, even if we grant that it's more difficult to guard against venial sins than criminal ones, it's nevertheless more fitting to avoid those that are more dangerous, that deserve greater punishment, and by which we believe God is more offended and which displease him more.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quo enim amplius ipsi per amorem inhaeremus, eo sollicitius cavere debemus quibus magis offenditur, et quae ipse magis improbat. Qui enim vere aliquem diligit, non tam damnum suum, quam offensam amici, vel contemptum cavere satagit, juxta illud Apostoli: Charitas non quaerit quae sua sunt; et rursum: Nemo quod suum est quaerat, sed quod alterius.
chunks.english: For the more we cling to him through love, the more carefully we should avoid what offends him more and what he disapproves of more. For whoever truly loves someone strives not so much to avoid his own harm as to avoid offending his friend or showing contempt, according to the Apostle's words: 'Love doesn't seek its own interests.' That's from Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter thirteen, verse five. And again: 'Let no one seek his own good, but that of another.' That's from the same letter, chapter ten, verse twenty-four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo, non tam pro nostro damno quam pro Dei offensa, debemus cavere peccata, profecto plus ea cavenda sunt, in quibus magis offenditur. Quod si illam quoque poeticam attendamus sententiam, de morum scilicet honestate: Oderunt peccare boni virtutis amore, tanto majori odio quaelibet sunt habenda, quanto turpiora in se censentur, et ab honestate virtutis amplius recedunt, et naturaliter quoslibet magis offendunt.
chunks.english: If therefore we should avoid sins not so much for our own harm as for offending God, certainly those sins should be more avoided in which he is more offended. And if we consider that poetic saying about moral virtue: 'The good hate to sin from love of virtue'that's from Horace's Epistles, book one, epistle sixteen, line fifty-seventhen anything should be held in greater hatred the more base it's considered in itself, the more it departs from the honor of virtue, and the more it naturally offends anyone.
chunks.notes: Citation from Horace, a Roman poet

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Denique, ut singula sibi conferendo diligentius peccata dijudicemus, comparemus venialia criminalibus, utpote superfluam comestionem perjurio et adulterio; et quaeramus, in transgressione cujus magis peccatur, vel amplius Deus contemnatur atque offendatur. Nescio, fortassis respondebis, cum nonnulli philosophorum omnia peccata paria censuerunt. At si hanc philosophiam, imo manifestam stultitiam sequi velis, aeque bonum a criminalibus et venialibus abstinere peccatis, quia aeque malum est haec et illa committere: cur ergo abstinere a venialibus praeferre quis audeat abstinentiae criminalium?
chunks.english: So then, to weigh individual sins more carefully by comparing them to one another, let's compare venial sins with mortal sinsfor instance, overeating with perjury and adulteryand ask which transgression involves greater sin, or in which God is more thoroughly scorned and offended. I don't knowperhaps you'll answer that some philosophers have considered all sins equal. But if you want to follow this philosophy, or rather this obvious foolishnessthat it's equally good to avoid both mortal and venial sins because committing either is equally badthen why would anyone dare to prefer avoiding venial sins over avoiding mortal ones?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si quis forte requirat unde conjicere possimus, Deo magis displicere transgressionem adulterii, quam superfluitatem cibi, lex divina, ut arbitror, docere nos potest, quae ad illud puniendum nullam poenae satisfactionem instituit; hoc vero non qualibet poena, sed summae mortis afflictione damnari decrevit.
chunks.english: If someone asks how we can determine that God is more displeased by the transgression of adultery than by excessive eating, divine law can teach us, I believe. The law established no penal satisfaction for punishing the latter, but decreed that the former should be condemned not with just any penalty but with the affliction of capital punishment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quo enim charitas proximi, quam Apostolus plenitudinem legis dicit, amplius laeditur, magis contra eam agitur, et amplius peccatur.
chunks.english: The more love of neighborwhich the Apostle calls the fullness of the lawis injured, the more one acts against it, and the greater the sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si ad hunc modum singulis venialibus pariter et criminalibus peccatis invicem collatis, simul etiam tam ista omnia, quam illa conferre velimus, ut omnino scilicet satisfacere valeamus, nequaquam refugio. Ponamus ergo ut aliquis magno studio ab omnibus venialibus caveat peccatis et nulla criminalia curet vitare, et cum illa omnia caveat, hoc praesumat: quis eum in hoc levius peccare judicabit, aut meliorem esse, si haec praecavens, illa incurrat?
chunks.english: Now if, following this method, we want to compare individual venial and mortal sins with each other, and then also compare all venial sins taken together with all mortal sins, so that we can fully settle the matterI don't shy away from this at all. So let's suppose someone is extremely careful to avoid all venial sins but doesn't bother to avoid mortal sins, and while avoiding all the former, presumes to commit the latter. Who will judge that this person sins less severely, or is better off, if by avoiding the venial sins he falls into the mortal ones?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Collatione itaque facta tam singulorum, ut diximus, quam omnium simul invicem peccatorum, liquere arbitror, non melius vel majoris perfectionis esse venialia peccata cavere, quam criminalia.
chunks.english: Therefore, having made the comparison both of individual sins, as I said, and of all sins taken together, I believe it's clear that it is not better or more perfect to avoid venial sins than mortal ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quis tamen, cum illa primum vitaverit, haec postmodum, ut oportet, vitare valuerit, in hoc quidem fateor virtutem ejus ad perfectionem pervenisse; nec tamen ideo posteriora, in quibus consummatio virtutis consistit, sunt prioribus praeferenda, nec tanta retributione sunt digna.
chunks.english: However, if someone has first avoided mortal sins and then manages to avoid venial sins as well, as one ought, I admit that in this his virtue has reached perfection. Nevertheless, these latter achievements, in which the consummation of virtue consists, should not be preferred to the former, nor do they deserve equal reward.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe namque in operatione alicujus aedificii minus agunt, qui perficiunt ipsum quam qui antea operati sunt, et qui extremo assere in consummatione operis posito ipsum perficiunt, ut sic domus perfecta fiat, quae dum imperfecta fuit domus, opus non erat.
chunks.english: Often in the construction of some building, those who complete it do less work than those who labored earlier, and those who put the final beam in place at the completion of the work bring it to perfectionso that the house becomes a finished house, which while incomplete was not yet a proper work at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sufficere hucusque arbitror nos ad cognitionem peccati, quantum memoriae occurrit, laborasse, ut eo melius caveri possit, quo diligentius cognitum fuerit. Mali quippe notitia justo deesse non potest, nec cavere quis vitium nisi cognitum valet.
chunks.english: I believe we've labored sufficiently up to this point for knowledge of sin, as much as memory allows, so that sin can be avoided all the better the more carefully it's been understood. After all, knowledge of evil cannot be lacking to the just person, nor can anyone avoid a vice unless it's known.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Reconciliation of Sinners with God
chunks.latin: CAP. XVII. De peccatorum reconciliatione.
chunks.english: Chapter seventeen: On the reconciliation of sinners.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quoniam plagam animae monstravimus, curationis remedium studeamus ostendere; unde illud Hieronymi: O medice, si peritus es, sicut posuisti causam morbi, ita indica sanitatis!
chunks.english: And since we've shown the wound of the soul, let's strive to show the remedy for its cure. Hence that saying of Jerome: O physician, if you are skilled, just as you have set out the cause of the disease, so indicate the cure!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum igitur peccando Deum offendimus, superest quibus ei modis reconciliari possimus. Tria itaque sunt in reconciliatione peccatoris ad Deum, poenitentia scilicet, confessio, satisfactio.
chunks.english: Since then by sinning we offend God, what remains is to understand by what means we can be reconciled to him. There are therefore three things in the reconciliation of the sinner to God: repentance, confession, and satisfaction.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The True Nature of Repentance
chunks.latin: CAP. XVIII. Quid proprie dicatur poenitentia?
chunks.english: Chapter eighteen: What is properly called repentance?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Poenitentia autem proprie dicitur: Dolor animi super ea, in quo deliquit, cum aliquem scilicet piget in aliquo excessisse (Sap. V, 2, 3). Haec autem poenitentia tum ex amore Dei accidit, et fructuosa est; tum damno aliquo, quo nollemus gravari, qualis est illa damnatorum poenitentia, de quibus scriptum est, Videntes turbabuntur terrore horribili, et mirabuntur in subitatione insperatae salutis, dicentes intra se, et poenitentiam agentes, et prae angustia spiritus gementes; hi sunt quos aliquando habuimus in derisu, etc.
chunks.english: Now repentance is properly defined as grief of soul over that in which one has transgressedthat is, when someone regrets having gone to excess in something, as in the book of Wisdom chapter five, verses two and three. But this repentance sometimes comes from love of God and is fruitful; at other times from some harm we don't want to suffer, like that repentance of the damned of whom Scripture says, as in the book of Wisdom, they will see and be troubled with terrible fear, and will marvel at the suddenness of unexpected salvation, saying within themselves and repenting and groaning through anguish of spirit: these are they whom we once held in derision, and so forth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Legimus et poenitentiam Judae super hoc quod Dominum tradiderat; quod non tam pro culpa peccati quam pro vilitate sui, qui se omnium judicio damnatum sentiebat credimus accidisse.
chunks.english: We also read of Judas's repentance over having betrayed the Lord, which we believe came not so much from guilt over his sin as from self-contempt, since he felt himself condemned in everyone's judgment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum enim quis alium pecunia, vel quo modo corruptum ad perditionem traxerit, nemini vilior, quam ei proditor habetur, et nemo ei minus se credit, quam is qui infidelitatem ejus amplius expertus est.
chunks.english: For when someone has corrupted another with money or by some means and drawn him to destruction, the betrayer is held in lower regard by no one than by him, and no one trusts him less than the person who has most fully experienced his faithlessness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Multos quippe quotidie de hac vita recessuros de flagitiis perpetratis poeniteri videmus, et gravi compunctione ingemiscere non tam amore Dei, quem offenderunt, vel odio peccati quod commiserunt, quam timore poenae in quam se praecipitari verentur.
chunks.english: Indeed, every day we see many who are about to depart this life repenting of the crimes they've committed and groaning with deep contritionnot so much from love of the God they've offended or hatred of the sin they've committed, but from fear of the punishment into which they're afraid they'll be cast.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui in eo quoque iniqui permanent, quod non tam eis iniquitas displicet culpae, quam, quae justa est, gravitas poenae; nec tantum odio habent id quod commiserunt, quia malum fuit, quam justum Dei judicium, quod in poena formidant, aequitatem potius quam iniquitatem odientes.
chunks.english: These people remain wicked in this regard: that the wickedness of their fault displeases them less than the severitywhich is justof the punishment, nor do they hate what they've committed because it was evil as much as they hate God's just judgment, which they fear in the punishment, hating justice rather than injustice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quos diu obcaecatos, atque vocatos ut a malitia sua converterentur, ita tandem in reprobum sensum divina justitia tradit, et caecitate pereussos a facie sua prorsus abjicit, ut ne salubris poenitentiae notitiam habeant, nec qualiter satisfaciendum sit advertere queant.
chunks.english: Those who have long been blinded and called to turn from their wickedness are at last handed over by divine justice to a reprobate mind, and struck with blindness are utterly cast from God's face, so that they have no knowledge of wholesome repentance and cannot perceive how satisfaction should be made.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam plurimos quippe quotidie cernimus morientes graviter ingemiscere, multum se accusare super usuris, rapinis, oppressionibus pauperum, vel in quibuscunque injuriis, quas commiserunt, et pro emendatione istorum sacerdotem consulere.
chunks.english: We see very many dying people daily groaning heavily, accusing themselves greatly concerning usury, plunder, oppression of the poor, or whatever injuries they've committed, and consulting a priest for the amendment of these things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus si hoc, ut oportet, primum consilium detur, ut venditis omnibus quae habent, restituant aliis quae abstulerunt, juxta illud Augustini: Si res aliena cum reddi possit, non redditur, non agitur poenitentia, sed fingitur; statim quam inanis eorum sit poenitentia, responsione sua profitentur.
chunks.english: If they're given this first counsel, as they ought to bethat having sold everything they possess, they should restore to others what they've taken, according to Augustine's saying: If someone else's property, which can be returned, is not returned, then repentance is not being performed but feignedimmediately their response reveals how empty their repentance is.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde ergo, inquiunt, domus mea viveret? quid filiis meis, quid uxori relinquerem? Unde se sustentare possent? Quibus illa primum Dominica occurrit increpatio: Stulte, hac nocte animam tuam repetunt a te, quae autem parasti cujus erunt? (Luc. XII, 20.)
chunks.english: 'How then,' they say, 'would my household live? What would I leave to my children, what to my wife? How could they support themselves?' To them comes first that rebuke from the Lord: Fool, this night they will demand your soul from you, and the things you have preparedwhose will they be? From the Gospel of Luke chapter twelve, verse twenty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: O miser, quicunque talis es, imo miserorum omnium miserrime, et stultorum stultissime, non provides quid tibi conserves, sed quid aliis thesaurizes? Qua prae sumptione Deum offendis, ad cujus horrendum judicium raperis, ut tuos habeas propitios, quos ditas de pauperum rapinis?
chunks.english: O wretched man, whoever you areindeed most wretched of all the wretched, and most foolish of all the foolishyou're not considering what you're preserving for yourself, but what treasure you're storing up for others. With what presumption do you offend God, to whose terrible judgment you're being dragged, so that your family might be favorable to you, whom you enrich from the plunder of the poor?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis super te non rideat, si audierit te sperare alios magis tibi propitios fore quam te ipsum? Confidis in eleemosynis tuorum, quos quia successores habere te credis, iniquitatis pariter haeredes constituis, quibus aliena per rapinam possidenda relinquis.
chunks.english: Who won't laugh at you if they hear that you hope others will be more favorable to you than you are to yourself? You trust in the alms of your familywhom, because you believe you'll have them as successors, you make heirs of iniquity as well, leaving them others' property to possess through plunder.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vitam pauperibus eripis sua illis auferendo, unde sunt sustentandi, et in eis rursum occidere Christum machinaris, juxta illud quod ipsemet ait: Quod uni ex minimis meis fecistis, mihi fecistis (Matth. XXV, 40).
chunks.english: You take away the life of the poor by removing their property by which they should be sustained, and in them you plot again to kill Christ, according to what he himself says: What you did to one of the least of mine, you did to me. From the Gospel of Matthew chapter twenty-five, verse forty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ergo tu male pius in tuos, et crudelis in te pariter atque Deum a judice justo exspectas, ad quem velis, nolis, judicandus properas, qui non solum de rapinis, sed etiam de otioso verbo rationem exigit?
chunks.english: What then do you, perversely devoted to your family and cruel to yourself and God alike, expect from the just Judge to whom, whether you wish it or not, you're hastening to be judgedhe who demands an account not only of plunder but even of every idle word?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui quam districtus sit in vindicta, priorum hominum statim exhibuit poena. Semel Adam peccavit, et comparatione nostrorum, sicut beatus meminit Hieronymus, levissimum ejus peccatum fuit. Non quemquam per violentiam oppressit, nec quidquam alicui abstulit; de fructu, qui reparabilis erat, semel gustavit.
chunks.english: How strict he is in punishment was immediately shown by the penalty inflicted on the first people. Adam sinned once, and by comparison with our sins, as blessed Jerome reminds us, his sin was very light. He oppressed no one through violence nor took anything from anyone; he tasted once of fruit that could be replaced.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In qua quidem tam levi transgressione, in posteritatem quoque totam per poenam redundata, praemonstrare Dominus decrevit, quid de majoribus facturus sit culpis.
chunks.english: In this very light transgression, which overflowed through punishment even into all posterity, the Lord decided to demonstrate in advance what he would do concerning greater faults.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dives, quem ad inferos Dominus descendisse dicit, non quod aliena rapuerit, sed quia propria, quibus tanquam licitis vescebatur, indigenti Lazaro non impertivit, patenter edocet, qua poena feriendi sunt, qui rapiunt aliena, si sic ille damnatus est atque in inferno sepultus, qui non tribuerit bona sua.
chunks.english: The rich man whom the Lord says descended to the underworldnot because he seized others' property, but because he didn't share his own, on which he feasted as if lawfully, with needy Lazarusclearly teaches what punishment must strike those who seize others' property, if he was thus condemned and buried in hell who did not give his own goods.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tecum memoria tui sepulta, et cito siccatis lacrymis eorum, quos in exsequiis habuisti, juxta rhetoris Apollonii: lacryma citius nihil arescit, tua conjux in proximo ad novas nuptias se praeparavit, ut novi mariti voluptatibus deserviret, de his quas ei dimisisti rapinis, et praesente adhuc corpore tuo lectulum calefaciet alieno, te misero in flammis gehennae voluptates istas plexuro. Idem et a filiis tuis exspectandum est.
chunks.english: With the memory of you buried with you, and the tears of those who attended your funeral quickly driedaccording to the rhetorician Apollonius: nothing dries faster than a tearyour wife has soon prepared herself for a new marriage, to serve the pleasures of a new husband with the plunder you left her, and while your body is still present she'll warm another man's bed, while you, wretched one, will pay for those pleasures in the flames of Gehenna. The same is to be expected from your children.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si quis forte interroget cur non tui recordantes eleemosynis suis tibi propitientur, multis se de causis excusare posse videntur.
chunks.english: Now if someone should perhaps ask why they don't remember you and propitiate you with their alms, they seem able to excuse themselves for many reasons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia enim, si respondeant: Cum ille sibi propitius esse noluerit, quanta stultitia fuit sibi alios sperare propitios, et animae suae salutem aliis committere, de qua ipse debuit plurimum providere: quem sibi propitium magis credidit quam se ipsum? Qui sibi crudelis erat, de cujus misericordia confidebat?
chunks.english: For they might respond: Since he refused to be favorable to himself, what foolishness it was for him to hope others would be favorable to him, and to entrust the salvation of his soul to others, for which he himself should have provided most abundantly. Whom did he believe would be more favorable to him than himself? He who was cruel to himselfin whose mercy was he placing his confidence?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Possunt denique et in excusationem avaritiae suae praetendere ac dicere: scimus insuper ea, quae ipse nobis dereliquit, non hujusmodi esse, ut de ipsis nobis sint eleemosynae faciendae. Ridebunt omnes, et ridere debent, qui haec audient.
chunks.english: Finally, they can even put forward in excuse of their own greed: We know moreover that what he left us is not of such a nature that alms should be given from it by us. Everyone will laugh, and ought to laugh, who hears these things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille vero miser, qui exspoliatos pauperes ad horam flere coegit, in perpetuum ibi flebit.
chunks.english: But that wretched man who forced despoiled paupers to weep for an hour will weep there forever.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt qui suam negligentiam hominibus non Deo volentes occultare, ad excusandas excusationes in peccatis dicunt, tot eos esse quos exspoliaverunt, ut omnino cognoscere vel reperire nequeant; de quo, cum nullam sollicitudinem assumant, illud Apostolicae sententiae judicium incurrunt: Et qui ignorat ignorabitur (I Cor. XIV, 38).
chunks.english: There are those who, wanting to hide their negligence from men but not from God, resort to excusing their excuses in their sins and say that those they've despoiled are so many that they cannot possibly know or find them at all. Because they assume no concern about this, they fall under that judgment of the Apostle's sentence: And whoever is ignorant will be ignored. From Paul's first letter to the Corinthians chapter fourteen, verse thirty-eight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non inveniunt illos, quia non quaerunt; inveniet illos dextera Dei, quem contempserunt. De qua etiam scriptum est: Dextera tua inveniet omnes qui te oderunt (Psal. XX, 9).
chunks.english: They don't find them because they don't seek them. The right hand of God, whom they despised, will find them. Concerning which it is also written: Your right hand will find all who hate you. From Psalm twenty, verse nine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam idem Propheta, qui hoc dixit, vehementer expavescens, et locum nullum evadendi considerans alibi ait: Quo ibo a spiritu tuo, et quo a facie tua fugiam? Si ascendero in coelum, tu illic es, si descendero in infernum, ades (Psal. CXXXVIII, 5).
chunks.english: The same prophet who said this, trembling greatly and considering no place of escape, says elsewhere: Where shall I go from your spirit, and where shall I flee from your face? If I ascend into heaven, you are there; if I descend into hell, you are present. From Psalm one hundred thirty-eight, verse five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia plerumque non minor est avaritia sacerdotis quam populi juxta illud prophetae: Et erit sicut sacerdotes, sic populus (Ose. IV, 9), multos morientium seducet cupiditas sacerdotum vanam eis securitatem promittentium, si quae habent, sacrificiis obtulerint, et missas emant, quas nequaquam gratis haberent.
chunks.english: And because often the avarice of the priest is no less than that of the people, according to that saying of the prophet: And it shall be like priest, like people, from Hosea chapter four, verse ninethe greed of priests promising them vain security will seduce many dying people, if they offer what they have for sacrifices and buy masses, which they would by no means have for free.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quo quidem mercimonio praefixum apud eos pretium constat esse, pro una scilicet missa unum denarium; et pro uno annuali quadraginta. Non consulunt morientibus ut rapinas restituant, sed ut in sacrificio ipsas offerant; cum e contrario scriptum sit: Qui offert sacrificium de substantia pauperis, quasi qui victimet filium in conspectu patris (Eccli. XXXIV, 24): plus enim gravat patrem occisio filii coram se facta, quam si non videret eam; et quasi filius immolatione occiditur, dum substantia pauperis, in qua vita ejus consistebat, in sacrificio ponitur.
chunks.english: In this trade a fixed price is established among them: one denarius for one mass, and forty for one annual cycle. They don't advise the dying to restore their plunder, but to offer it in sacrifice. Yet Scripture says the contrary: Whoever offers sacrifice from the substance of the poor is like one who slaughters a son in his father's presence. From Ecclesiasticus chapter thirty-four, verse twenty-four. For the killing of a son done before the father burdens him more than if he didn't see it. And the son is as it were killed by immolation when the substance of the poor, in which his life consisted, is placed in sacrifice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et veritas sacrificio misericordiam praeferens, euntes, inquit, discite quid est, misericordiam volo, et non sacrificium (Matth. IX, 13). Pejus autem est rapinas retinere, quam misericordiam non impendere, hoc est, pauperibus auferre sua quam non impendere nostra, sicut et supra in damnatione divitis meminimus.
