chunks.english: And Truth, preferring mercy to sacrifice, says: Go and learn what this means: I desire mercy and not sacrifice. From the Gospel of Matthew chapter nine, verse thirteen. But it's worse to retain plunder than not to show mercythat is, to take away from the poor what is theirs rather than not to give what is ours, as we mentioned above in the condemnation of the rich man.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Fruitful Repentance from Love of God
chunks.latin: CAP. XIX. De fructuosa poenitentia.
chunks.english: Chapter nineteen: On fruitful repentance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia de infructuosa diximus poenitentia, tanto diligentius quanto salubrius fructuosam consideremus. Ad quam Apostolus quemlibet invitans obstinatum, nec horrendum Dei judicium attendentem, ait: An divitias bonitatis ejus et patientiae, et longanimitatis contemnis? Ignoras quoniam benignitas Dei ad poenitentiam te adducit? (Rom. II, 4.)
chunks.english: And since we've spoken of fruitless repentance, let's consider fruitful repentance all the more diligently because it's more wholesome. The Apostle, inviting anyone who is obstinate and not paying attention to God's terrible judgment, says: Or do you despise the riches of his goodness and patience and forbearance? Are you ignorant that God's kindness is leading you to repentance? From Paul's letter to the Romans chapter two, verse four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus videlicet verbis quae sit poenitentia salubris, et ex amore Dei potius quam ex timore proveniens, manifeste declarat, ut videlicet doleamus Deum offendisse vel contempsisse, quia est bonus, magis quam quia justus est.
chunks.english: By these words he clearly declares what wholesome repentance is, and that it comes from love of God rather than from fearnamely, that we should grieve for having offended or despised God because he is good, rather than because he is just.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quo enim diutius eum contemnimus, quia statim eum contemptum suum judicare non credimus, sicut e contrario principes saeculi faciunt, qui cum offenduntur, nesciunt parcere, nec suarum injuriarum ultionem differre, eo justius graviorem infert sui contemptus poenam; et tanto districtior est in ultionem, quanto patientior fuit in exspectatione.
chunks.english: The longer we despise himbecause we don't believe he immediately judges the contempt shown to him, unlike earthly princes who, when offended, don't know how to spare or delay revenge for their injuriesthe more justly he inflicts a heavier punishment for contempt of himself. And he is all the more severe in vengeance the more patient he was in waiting.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod subsequenter praedictus Apostolus ostendit dicens: Secundum duritiam autem tuam et cor impoenitens, thesaurizas tibi iram in die irae (ibid., 5); tunc quidem irae, modo mansuetudinis, quia tunc vindictae, modo patientiae.
chunks.english: The same Apostle shows this subsequently when he says: But according to your hardness and impenitent heart, you are storing up wrath for yourself on the day of wrath. From the same chapter, verse five. Then indeed wrath, now gentleness; then vengeance, now patience.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ibi justitia exigente tanto gravius sui contemptum ulciscetur, quanto minus contemni debuit, et diutius toleravit.
chunks.english: There, as justice demands, he will avenge contempt of himself all the more severely the less he deserved to be despised and the longer he endured it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Timemus homines offendere, et quorum offensam timore non effugimus, verecundia vitamus. Latebras quaerimus, cum fornicamur, ne ab hominibus videamur, nec unius hominis aspectum tunc sustinere possumus. Scimus Deum praesentem esse, quem nihil potest latere; videri ab ipso et tota curia coeli in hujus actione turpitudinis non erubescimus, qui ad unius homunculi aspectum confunderemur.
chunks.english: We fear offending people, and whose offense we don't escape by fear, we avoid through shame. We seek hiding places when we fornicate, lest we be seen by people, nor can we then bear the sight of even one person. We know God is present, from whom nothing can be hidden. Yet we're not ashamed to be seen by him and the whole court of heaven in this shameful act, though we'd be confounded at the sight of one insignificant person.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ante judicem terrenum praesumere aliquid maxime timemus, a quo nos judicandos scimus temporali tantum poena, non aeterna. Multa nos facere vel tolerare carnalis affectus cogit, pauca spiritualis. Utinam tanta propter Deum, cui omnia debemus, quanta propter uxorem vel filios, vel quamcunque meretricem facimus vel toleramus!
chunks.english: Before an earthly judge we're especially afraid to presume anything, knowing we'll be judged by him with only temporal punishment, not eternal. Carnal affection compels us to do or endure many things, spiritual affection few. Would that we did or endured as much for God, to whom we owe everything, as we do or endure for a wife or children or any prostitute!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qua, obsecro, poena haec injuria est judicanda ut meretricem quoque ipsi praeponamus? Conqueritur ipse per prophetam quod nec ei amor tanquam Patri, nec timor exhibeatur tanquam Domino: Filius, inquit, honorat patrem, et servus dominum suum timet; si ego Pater, ubi honor meus? Et si ego Dominus, ubi timor meus? (Malach. I, 6.)
chunks.english: By what punishment, I ask, should this injury be judgedthat we even prefer a prostitute to him? He himself complains through the prophet that neither love is shown to him as Father nor fear as Lord: A son honors his father, and a servant fears his lord; if I am Father, where is my honor? And if I am Lord, where is my fear? From Malachi chapter one, verse six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Conqueritur sibi patrem vel dominum praeferri. Attende igitur, quantum indignetur, meretricem quoque sibi anteferri, et de summa suae bonitatis patientia, unde plus debuit amari, magis contemni.
chunks.english: He complains that a father or lord is preferred to him. Consider therefore how indignant he must be that even a prostitute is preferred to him, and that because of the supreme patience of his goodness, for which he should be more loved, he is more despised.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam quidem bonitatem, et patientiae longanimitatem hi qui salubriter poenitent attendentes, non tam timore poenarum quam ipsius amore, ad compunctionem moventur, juxta praedictam Apostoli exhortationem ubi salubrem poenitentiam diligenter descripsit; cum e contrario dixit: an divitias bonitatis ejus, hoc est divitem et copiosam bonitatem, sive abundantem benignitatem longanimis patientiae, qua tam diu te tolerat, contemnis, quia videlicet non cito punit; ignorans, hoc est non attendens, quoniam tanta ejus benignitas ad poenitentiam, quantum in se est, te adducit, hoc est facit cur eam attendendo ad poenitentiam deberes converti, quod tam benignum contempsisti?
chunks.english: Those who repent wholesomely, considering indeed this goodness and the forbearance of his patience, are moved to compunction not so much by fear of punishments as by love of him, according to the aforementioned exhortation of the Apostle where he carefully described wholesome repentance when he said conversely: Or do you despise the riches of his goodnessthat is, the rich and abundant goodness, or the overflowing kindness of longsuffering patience by which he has tolerated you for so longbecause he doesn't punish quickly? Are you ignorantthat is, not paying attentionthat his kindness, as far as it concerns him, leads you to repentance? That is, it creates the reason why, by paying attention to it, you should turn to repentance: that you have despised one so kind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et haec quidem revera fructuosa est poenitentia peccati, cum hic dolor, atque contritio animi ex amore Dei, quem tam benignum attendimus, potius quam ex timore poenarum procedit.
chunks.english: And this indeed is truly fruitful repentance for sin, when this grief and contrition of soul proceeds from love of God, whom we recognize as so kind, rather than from fear of punishments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum hoc autem gemitu et contritione cordis, quam veram poenitentiam dicimus, peccatum non permanet, hoc est contemptus Dei, sive consensus in malum, quia charitas Dei hunc gemitum inspirans, non patitur culpam.
chunks.english: Now with this groaning and contrition of heart, which we call true repentance, sin does not remainthat is, contempt of God or consent to evilbecause the love of God that inspires this groaning does not tolerate guilt.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In hoc statim gemitu Deo reconciliamur, et praecedentis peccati veniam assequimur, juxta illud prophetae: Quacunque hora peccator ingemuerit, salvus erit (Ezech. XXXIII, 14); hoc est, salute animae suae dignus efficietur.
chunks.english: In this groaning we are immediately reconciled to God and obtain pardon for our previous sin, according to that saying of the prophet: At whatever hour the sinner groans, he will be saved. From Ezekiel chapter thirty-three, verse fourteen. That is, he will be made worthy of the salvation of his soul.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non ait: quo anno, vel quo mense, sive qua hebdomada, vel quo die, sed qua hora: ut sine dilatione venia dignum ostendat; nec ei poenam aeternam deberi, in qua consistit condemnatio peccati.
chunks.english: He doesn't say: in what year, or in what month, or in what week, or on what day, but at what hourto show that one is worthy of pardon without delay, and that eternal punishment, in which the condemnation of sin consists, is not owed to him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Etsi enim articulo necessitatis praeventus non habeat locum veniendi ad confessionem, vel peragendi satisfactionem, nequaquam in hoc gemitu de hac vita recedens gehennam incurrit; quod est condonari a Deo peccatum, hoc est, eum talem fieri, quam jam non sit dignum sicut animam propter illud quod praecessit peccatum, aeternaliter a Deo puniri.
chunks.english: For even if overtaken by the moment of necessity he doesn't have opportunity to come to confession or to perform satisfaction, by no means does he who departs this life in this groaning fall into Gehenna. For sin to be forgiven by God means this: that he becomes such that it's no longer fitting for his soul to be eternally punished by God on account of the sin that preceded.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim Deus cum peccatum poenitentibus condonat, omnem poenam eis ignoscit, sed solummodo aeternam. Multi namque poenitentes, qui praeventi morte, satisfactionem poenitentiae in hac vita non egerunt, poenis purgatoriis, non damnatoriis in futura reservantur.
chunks.english: For when God forgives sin to the penitent, he doesn't remit all punishment to them, but only the eternal. Indeed, many penitent people who, overtaken by death, didn't perform the satisfaction of penance in this life, are reserved for purifying punishments in the future life, not damning ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde suprema judicii dies, qua repente multi fidelium puniendi sunt, quanto spatio temporis extendatur, incertum est; quamvis resurrectio in momento, in ictu oculi fiat (I Cor. XV, 52); ut videlicet ibi de culpis satisfaciant, quantum Deus decreverit, de quibus satisfacere distulerint, aut permissi non sunt.
chunks.english: Hence the supreme day of judgment, on which suddenly many of the faithful must be punished, extends over an uncertain span of time, although the resurrection happens in a moment, in the blink of an eye, as in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians chapter fifteen, verse fifty-twoso that there they may make satisfaction for their faults as much as God has decreed, for which they either delayed making satisfaction or were not permitted to do so.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Can One Repent of One Sin Without Another
chunks.latin: CAP. XX. Utrum quis de uno peccato sine altero poenitere possit.
chunks.english: Chapter twenty: Whether one can repent of one sin without repenting of another.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt qui quaerunt, utrum quis de uno peccato poenitere possit, et non de alio, utpote de homicidio, et non de fornicatione, quam adhuc perpetrare non desistit?
chunks.english: Some ask whether one can repent of one sin and not of anotherfor instance, of murder but not of fornication, which one doesn't yet cease to commit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed si fructuosam illam poenitentiam intelligamus, quam Dei amor immittit, et quam Gregorius describens ait: Poenitentia est commissa deflere, et flenda non committere, nequaquam poenitentia dici potest, ad quam nos amor Dei compellit, quoties unus contemptus retinetur.
chunks.english: But if we understand that fruitful repentance which love of God instills, and which Gregory describing says: Repentance is to weep for what has been committed and not to commit what should be wept forby no means can it be called repentance, to which love of God compels us, whenever one contempt is retained.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim amor Dei, sicut oportet, ad hoc me inducit, atque animum trahit, ut de hoc consensu doleam propter hoc tantum quia in eo Deum offendi, non video qualiter idem amor de illo contemptu eadem de causa poenitere non cogat; hoc est, in eo proposito mentem meam statuat, ut quis excessus meus memoriae occurrerit, de ipso similiter doleam, et ad satisfaciendum paratus sim.
chunks.english: For if love of God, as it should, leads me to this and draws my mind so that I grieve over this consent solely because in it I offended God, I don't see how the same love doesn't compel me to repent of that contempt for the same reasonthat is, establish my mind in such a purpose that whatever transgression of mine comes to memory, I similarly grieve over it and am prepared to make satisfaction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ubicunque igitur vera est poenitentia, ex amore scilicet Dei solo proveniens, nullus Dei contemptus remanet, maxime cum Veritas dicat: Si quis diligit me, sermonem meum servabit, et Pater meus diliget eum, et ad eum veniemus, et mansionem apud eum faciemus (Joan. XIV, 23).
chunks.english: Therefore wherever there is true repentancethat is, coming from love of God aloneno contempt of God remains, especially since Truth says: If anyone loves me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our dwelling with him. From the Gospel of John chapter fourteen, verse twenty-three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quicunque ergo in amore Dei persistunt, salvari necesse est: quae salvatio nequaquam contingeret uno peccato, id est uno Dei contemptu retento.
chunks.english: Therefore whoever persists in love of God must necessarily be savedwhich salvation would by no means occur with one sin, that is, one contempt of God, retained.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum autem in poenitente jam nullum Deus reperit peccatum, nullam ibi invenit damnationis causam; et ideo necesse est ut, peccato cessante, non restet damnatio, hoc est, perennis poenae afflictio; et hoc est peccatum quod praecessit, a Deo condonari a poena aeterna, quam inde meruerat ei, ut diximus, a Deo provideri.
chunks.english: But when God finds no sin remaining in the penitent, he finds there no cause of condemnation. And therefore it's necessary that, with sin ceasing, condemnation does not remainthat is, the affliction of perpetual punishment. And this means that the sin that preceded is forgiven by God from the eternal punishment which it had merited, as we said, being provided for by God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quamvis enim Deus jam non inveniat in poenitente, quod perenniter debeat punire, poenam tamen praecedentis peccati dicitur condonare, cum per hoc, quod gemitum ei poenitentiae inspiraverit, eum indulgentia dignum fecit; hoc est, talem, cui nulla tunc debeatur poena aeterna, et quem in hoc statu de hac vita recedentem salvari necesse est.
chunks.english: For although God no longer finds in the penitent what he should punish perpetually, he is nevertheless said to forgive the punishment of the preceding sin when by inspiring in him the groaning of repentance, he has made him worthy of indulgencethat is, such a person to whom no eternal punishment is then owed, and who, departing this life in this state, must necessarily be saved.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si forte et in eumdem recidat contemptum, sicut redit ad peccatum, ita etiam relabitur ad poenae debitum, ut rursum puniri debeat, qui prius poenitendo non puniri meruerat.
chunks.english: But if perhaps he falls back into the same contempt, just as he returns to sin, so also he relapses into the obligation of punishment, so that he who by repenting had merited not to be punished must again be punished.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quis forte dicat: Peccatum a Deo condonari, tale esse tanquam si diceretur: Deum, propter illud quod commissum est, nequaquam hominem esse damnaturum; vel hoc: Deum apud se statuisse ut eum propter hoc non damnaret: profecto et antequam poenitens peccasset, concedendum videtur Deum condonasse illud peccatum; hoc est apud se statuisse, quod propter illud non esset eum damnaturus: nihil quippe recenter apud se Deus statuit, vel disponit, sed ab aeterno quaecunque facturus est, in ejus praedestinatione consistunt et in ejus providentia praefixa sunt, tam de condonatione cujuscunque peccati, quam de caeteris quae fiunt.
chunks.english: If someone should perhaps say that for sin to be forgiven by God means that God will by no means damn a person on account of what was committed, or that God has determined within himself not to damn him on account of thisthen indeed even before the penitent sinned, God seems to have forgiven that sin, that is, determined within himself that he would not damn him on account of it. For God doesn't recently determine or arrange anything within himself, but from eternity whatever he's going to do exists in his predestination and is fixed in his providence, both concerning the forgiveness of any sin and concerning other things that happen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Melius itaque nobis esse videtur ita intelligendum Deum condonare peccatum, quemlibet, ut diximus, per inspiratum ei poenitentiae gemitum dignum indulgentia efficere; hoc est, talem, cui tunc damnatio non debeatur, nec unquam ulterius, si in tali proposito perseveret.
chunks.english: Therefore it seems better to us that we should understand God forgiving sin thus: that he makes anyone, as we said, worthy of indulgence through the groaning of repentance inspired in himthat is, such a person to whom damnation is not then owed, nor ever afterwards, if he perseveres in such a purpose.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Peccatum itaque Deus condonat, cum ipse, a quo poena fieri debuit, faciat, poenitentiam inspirando, cur jam non debeat inferri.
chunks.english: Therefore God forgives sin when he himself, from whom punishment should come, brings it about, by inspiring repentance, that it should no longer be inflicted.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Justice of Withholding Unmerited Reward
chunks.latin: CAP. XXI. Injustum non esse, dignum praemio non donari
chunks.english: Chapter twenty-one: That it's not unjust for a reward not to be given to one worthy of it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed fortassis requiris, si is qui poenitet, jam dignus sit vita aeterna, qui damnatione dignus non est? Quod si concedamus, objicitur nobis, eum quoque, qui post poenitentiam lapsus periit, dum poeniteret, dignum vita aeterna fuisse; et Deum arguendum injuriae esse videri, qui praemium, quo ille tunc dignus erat, ei tunc saltem non reddidit, ut sic ejus damnationem praeveniret.
chunks.english: But perhaps you ask: if one who repents is now worthy of eternal life, since he's not worthy of damnation? If we grant this, it's objected to us that even one who, having lapsed after repentance, perished, was worthy of eternal life while he was repenting. And it seems God should be accused of injustice because he didn't at least then give him the reward of which he was then worthy, so as to prevent his damnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut enim si tunc moreretur, ex illo, in quo tunc erat, proposito, dignus vita aeterna salvaretur: ita et si postea lapsus sit, ex eodem animo quem prius habuit, dignus salvari fuit.
chunks.english: For just as if he had died then, from that purpose in which he then was, he would be saved as worthy of eternal life, so also if he later fell, from the same disposition he previously had, he was worthy to be saved.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed dico quia sicut multi saepe damnatione digni sunt, nec tamen in hac sua nequitia moriuntur, ut damnatio quam meruerant eis a Deo reddatur; nec tamen ideo Deus injustitiae est arguendus, quia non reddidit eis poenam quam meruerant: ita nec in praemiis reddendis, quae perseverantibus tantum promittuntur, Veritate attestante: Qui perseveraverit usque in finem, hic salvus erit (Matth. X, 22).
chunks.english: But I say that just as many are often worthy of damnation, yet don't die in their wickedness so that the damnation they merited be rendered to them by Godnor is God therefore to be accused of injustice because he didn't render to them the punishment they meritedso neither in rendering rewards, which are promised only to those who persevere, as Truth attests: Whoever perseveres to the end will be saved. From the Gospel of Matthew chapter ten, verse twenty-two.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non ergo concedere cogimur, ut quia quandoque poena vel praemio quis dignus fuerit, ideo dignum vel justum sit, Deum illud ei conferre, cum alio modo melius utendum eo esse providerit, quia etiam malis bene utitur, et quaeque pessima optime disponit.
chunks.english: Therefore we're not forced to concede that because someone was at some time worthy of punishment or reward, it's therefore fitting or just for God to confer it on him, since God has foreseen that it's better to use him another way, because he uses even evil things well and arranges the worst things in the best way.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si forte quis dicat, eum, qui ad horam Deum amando, vere poenituit, sed tamen in hac poenitentia vel amore non perseveraverit, non ideo fuisse praemio dignum vitae: profecto cum nec tunc damnatione dignus fuisse conceditur, nec justus, nec peccator tunc exstitisse videbitur.
chunks.english: But if perhaps someone says that one who, loving God for a time, truly repented but nevertheless didn't persevere in this repentance or love, was not therefore worthy of the reward of lifecertainly since it's granted that he wasn't then worthy of damnation either, he will seem to have been then neither just nor a sinner.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Unforgivable Sin Against the Holy Spirit
chunks.latin: CAP. XXII. De peccato irremissibili.
chunks.english: Chapter twenty-two: On the unforgivable sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum autem, ut diximus, omne peccatum per poenitentiam statim remissionem accipiat, quaeritur, cur Veritas quoddam peccatum irremissibile dixerit, vel nunquam ipsum remissionem, hoc est, condonationem, habiturum; quale est illud peccatum blasphemiae in Spiritum sanctum, de quo eum dixisse Matthaeus sic refert: Omne peccatum et blasphemia remittetur hominibus, Spiritus autem blasphemia non remittetur (Luc. XII, 31); et: Quicunque dixerit verbum contra Filium hominis, remittetur ei; qui autem dixerit contra Spiritum sanctum, non remittetur ei neque in hoc saeculo, neque in futuro? (ibid., 32; XII, 10.)
chunks.english: But since, as we said, every sin immediately receives forgiveness through repentance, it's asked why Truth said that a certain sin is unforgivable, or would never have forgiveness, that is, pardon. Such is that sin of blasphemy against the Holy Spirit, about which Matthew reports him saying: Every sin and blasphemy will be forgiven men, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven. From the Gospel of Luke chapter twelve, verse thirty-one. And: Whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man, it will be forgiven him; but whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit, it will not be forgiven him either in this age or in the future. From the same Gospel, chapter twelve, verse ten.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod quare diceret, Marcus aperuit dicens: Quoniam dicebant: Spiritum immundum habet (Marc. III, 30).
chunks.english: Mark explained why he said this when he wrote: Because they said, He has an unclean spirit. From the Gospel of Mark chapter three, verse thirty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hoc autem peccatum quidam desperationem veniae dicunt; cum quis videlicet ob magnitudinem peccatorum diffidit penitus a bonitate Dei, quae per Spiritum sanctum intelligitur, ut nec poenitendo, vel aliqua satisfactione veniam possit impetrare.
chunks.english: Now some say this sin is despair of pardon, when someone on account of the magnitude of sins utterly loses confidence in the goodness of God, which is understood through the Holy Spirit, so that he cannot obtain pardon either by repenting or by any satisfaction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed si hoc dicimus peccare vel blasphemare in Spiritum, quid dicemus peccare in Filium hominis?
chunks.english: But if we say this is to sin or blaspheme against the Spirit, what shall we say it is to sin against the Son of Man?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantum vero mihi videtur, peccare vel blasphemare in Filium hominis hoc loco dicitur excellentiae humanitatis Christi derogare, tanquam eam negaremus sine peccato conceptam, vel a Deo assumptam propter visibilem carnis infirmitatem. Id quippe nulla humana ratione comperi poterat, sed Deo tantum revelanti credi.
chunks.english: As it seems to me, to sin or blaspheme against the Son of Man in this context means to detract from the excellence of Christ's humanity, as if denying that it was conceived without sin or assumed by God, on account of the visible weakness of the flesh. This indeed could not be grasped by any human reasoning, but only believed through God's revelation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tale est ergo quod ait: Omne peccatum et blasphemia remittetur hominibus; Spiritus autem blasphemia non remittetur, tanquam si diceret: De nulla alia blasphemia diffinitum est apud Deum, quod nullis hominibus dimittatur, nisi de ista; et quicunque dixerit verbum contra Filium hominis remittetur ei, hoc est, nullus qui assumpti hominis dignitati, ut diximus, deroget, propter hoc damnabitur, si aliae non interveniant damnationis causae.
chunks.english: Therefore what he says is this: Every sin and blasphemy will be forgiven men, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgivenas if he were saying: Concerning no other blasphemy has it been determined by God that it will be forgiven to no men, except this one. And whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man, it will be forgiven himthat is, no one who detracts from the dignity of the assumed man, as we said, will be damned on this account, if other causes of damnation don't intervene.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim in hoc aliquis contemptu Dei notari potest, si veritatem per errorem contradicat, nec contra conscientiam agat, maxime cum id tale sit, quod humana ratione investigari non possit, sed magis rationi videatur contrarium.
chunks.english: For in this no one can be marked with contempt of God if he contradicts the truth through error and doesn't act against his conscience, especially when this is something that cannot be investigated by human reason but rather seems contrary to reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Blasphemare autem in Spiritum est ita opera manifestae gratiae Dei calumniari, ut illa, quae credebant per Spiritum sanctum, hoc est, divina bonitate misericorditer fieri, per diabolum tamen assererent agi, tanquam si dicerent illum, quem Spiritum Dei credebant, esse spiritum nequam, et sic Deum esse diabolum.
chunks.english: But to blaspheme against the Spirit is to slander the works of God's manifest grace in such a way that those things which they believed were done mercifully through the Holy Spirit, that is, by divine goodness, they nevertheless asserted were accomplished through the devilas if saying that he whom they believed to be the Spirit of God was an evil spirit, and thus that God was the devil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quicunque igitur sic in Christum peccaverunt, dicendo scilicet contra conscientiam eum in Beelzebub principe daemoniorum ejicere daemonia, ita prorsus a regno Dei sunt proscripti, et ab ejus gratia penitus exclusi, ut nullus illorum deinceps per poenitentiam mereretur indulgentiam.
chunks.english: Therefore whoever thus sinned against Christ by saying against their conscience that he cast out demons by Beelzebub the prince of demons, are so utterly banished from the kingdom of God and completely excluded from his grace that none of them would henceforth merit indulgence through repentance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec quidem negamus eos salvari posse si poeniterent, sed solummodo eos dicimus nec poenitentiae actus assecuturos esse.
chunks.english: Nor indeed do we deny that they could be saved if they repented, but we only say that they won't even attain the actions of repentance.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Whether Penitents Carry Grief Into Eternity
chunks.latin: CAP. XXIII. Utrum poenitentes gemitum sui doloris hinc secum deferant?
chunks.english: Chapter twenty-three: Whether penitents carry the groaning of their grief with them from here.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quaerit fortassis aliquis, utrum hi, qui de hac vita poenitentes recedunt in hoc gemitu cordis et contritione doloris, ubi verum Deo sacrificium offertur juxta illud: Sacrificium Deo spiritus contribulatus (Psal. L), utrum, inquam, tales de hac luce migrantes hunc gemitum et dolorem secum deferant; ut in vita quoque illa coelesti haec se commisisse doleant, quo, ut scriptum est, aufugit dolor et gemitus (Isa. XXXV, 10), atque tristitia.
chunks.english: Perhaps someone asks whether those who depart this life as penitents in this groaning of heart and contrition of griefwhere a true sacrifice is offered to God according to that verse: A sacrifice to God is a troubled spirit, from Psalm fiftywhether, I say, such people migrating from this light carry this groaning and grief with them, so that in that heavenly life too they grieve over having committed these things, to which place, as Scripture says, pain and groaning flee away, from Isaiah chapter thirty-five, verse ten, and sadness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed profecto sicut Deo vel angelis peccata nostra sine aliqua poena doloris displicent, eo videlicet quod illa non approbant, quae mala considerant; ita et tunc nobis illa displicebunt, in quibus deliquimus.
chunks.english: But certainly just as our sins displease God and the angels without any pain of griefnamely because they don't approve what they consider evilso also then those things in which we transgressed will displease us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed utrum nos illa fecisse velimus, quae bene ordinata esse a Deo scimus, et nobis quoque in bonum cooperata, juxta illud Apostoli: Scimus quoniam diligentibus Deum omnia cooperantur in bonum (Rom. VIII, 28), alia est quaestio, quam pro viribus nostris tertio Theologiae nostro libro absolvimus.
chunks.english: But whether we would wish to have done those things which we know were well-ordered by God and also worked together for our good, according to that saying of the Apostle: We know that for those who love God all things work together for good, from Paul's letter to the Romans chapter eight, verse twenty-eightthis is another question which we resolved according to our ability in the third book of our Theology.

chunks.chapter_title: On Confession

chunks.english: Chapter twenty-four: On confession.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Patenter itaque Origenes ostendit, sicut et manifesta ratio habet, quod in his quae diximus, Petro concessum est, nequaquam omnibus episcopis a Domino collatum esse; sed his solis, qui Petrum non ex sublimitate cathedrae, sed meritorum imitantur dignitate.
chunks.english: Origen clearly demonstrates, as plain reason also confirms, that what we have discussed was granted to Peter but was by no means conferred by the Lord upon all bishops. Rather, it was given only to those who imitate Peter not through the loftiness of their episcopal throne, but through the dignity of their merits.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim suam voluntatem sequentes, et a voluntate Dei se avertentes contra divinae rectitudinis justitiam quidquam possunt; nec cum inique aliquid agunt, ad iniquitatem Deum inclinare possunt, ut eum quasi similem sui efficiant.
chunks.english: For those who follow their own will and turn away from God's will cannot do anything against the justice of divine righteousness. When they act unjustly, they cannot incline God toward injustice or make him somehow similar to themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quales quidem ipse vehementer arguens, et graviter eis comminans ait: Existimasti inique quod ero tui similis, arguam te, et statuam contra faciem tuam: intelligite haec qui obliviscimini Deum, etc.
chunks.english: The Lord himself vehemently rebukes such people and threatens them gravely, saying: You wickedly thought that I would be like you. I will rebuke you and set this before your face. Understand this, you who forget God. This comes from the Psalms, chapter forty-nine, verse twenty-one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis enim magis Deum oblivisci, et in reprobum sensum dari dicendus est, quam qui hanc sibi arrogat potestatem, ut in subjectis pro arbitrio suo ligandis atque solvendis divinam sibi subjacere sententiam dicat; ut quod etiam injuste praesumpserit, summam Dei justitiam pervertere queat: quasi reos, vel innocentes facere possit quos voluerit.
chunks.english: Who can be said to forget God more completely, or to be given over to a depraved mind, than the one who arrogates to himself this power: claiming that the divine judgment is subject to his will in binding and loosing his subjects according to his own arbitrary decision? As if his unjust presumption could overturn the supreme justice of God, as if he could make guilty or innocent whomever he wishes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod ne unquam praesumant, magnus ille doctor Ecclesiae Augustinus, et inter ipsos episcopos praeclarus occurrit sexto decimo sermone de verbis Domini dicens: Coepisti habere fratrem tuum tanquam publicanum; ligas eum in terra; sed ut juste alliges vide: nam injusta vincula disrumpit justitia.
chunks.english: To prevent anyone from ever making such presumptions, that great teacher of the Church, Augustine, who was himself a distinguished bishop, confronts this in his sixteenth sermon on the Lord's words, saying: You have begun to regard your brother as a tax collector. You bind him on earth. But take care that you bind him justly, for justice breaks unjust chains.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Beatus quoque Gregorius patenter asserit, et dominicis convincit exemplis, nihil ecclesiasticam potestatem in ligando vel solvendo posse, si deviet ab aequitate justitiae, et non divino concordet judicio.
chunks.english: The blessed Gregory also openly asserts, and proves through the Lord's own examples, that ecclesiastical power can accomplish nothing in binding or loosing if it deviates from the equity of justice and does not accord with divine judgment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde illud est quod ait in Evangeliorum homilia vicesima quinta: Plerumque contingit, ut locum judicis teneat, cujus ad locum vita minime concordat; ac saepe agitur, ut vel damnet immeritos, vel alios ipse ligatus solvat.
chunks.english: This is why he says in his twenty-fifth homily on the Gospels: It often happens that someone holds the position of judge whose life in no way corresponds to that position, and it frequently occurs that he either condemns the undeserving, or while bound himself, he looses others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe in solvendis vel ligandis subditis suae voluntatis motus, non autem causarum merita sequitur; unde fit ut ipsa ligandi et solvendi potestate se privet, qui hanc pro suis voluntatibus, et non pro subditorum moribus exercet.
chunks.english: Often in loosing or binding his subjects, he follows the impulses of his own will rather than the merits of the cases. Thus it happens that he deprives himself of the very power of binding and loosing when he exercises it according to his own wishes rather than according to the conduct of his subjects.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe fit ut erga quemlibet proximum odio vel gratia moveatur pastor. Judicare autem digne de subditis nequeunt, qui in subditorum causis sua vel alia vel gratiam sequuntur: unde per prophetam: Mortificabant animas quae non moriuntur, et vivificabant animas quae non vivunt.
chunks.english: It often happens that a pastor is moved toward someone by either hatred or favoritism. But those who follow their own interests or favoritism in the cases of their subjects cannot judge worthily concerning them. As the prophet says: They killed souls that should not die, and gave life to souls that should not live.
chunks.notes: Reference to Ezekiel 13:19

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non morientem quippe mortificat, qui justum damnat; et non victurum vivificare nititur, qui reum a supplicio absolvere conatur: causae ergo pensandae sunt, ac tunc ligandi atque solvendi potestas exercenda est; videndum quae culpa, aut quae sit poenitentia secuta post culpam: ut suos Omnipotens per compunctionis gratiam visitat, illos pastoris sententia absolvat.
chunks.english: Indeed, he who condemns the just kills one who should not die, and he who attempts to absolve the guilty from punishment tries to give life to one who will not live. Therefore, cases must be weighed carefully, and only then should the power of binding and loosing be exercised. One must consider what the fault is, and what penitence has followed the fault, so that the pastor's sentence may absolve those whom the Almighty visits through the grace of compunction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc enim vera est absolutio praesidentis, cum tantum sequitur arbitrium judicis. Quod bene quatriduani mortui resuscitatio illa significat; quae videlicet demonstrat, quia prius Dominus mortuum vocavit, et vivificat dicens: Lazare, veni foras; et postmodum is, qui vivus egressus fuerat a discipulis est solutus.
chunks.english: For the presiding authority's absolution is true only when it follows the judgment of the supreme Judge. This is well signified by the raising of Lazarus, who had been dead four days. That miracle demonstrates that the Lord first called the dead man and gave him life, saying: Lazarus, come out. Only afterward was the one who had come out alive unbound by the disciples.
chunks.notes: Reference to John 11:43-44

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item: Ecce illum discipuli jam solvunt, quem Magister suscitaverat mortuum; si enim mortuum Lazarum discipuli solverent, foetorem magis ostenderent quam virtutem.
chunks.english: Gregory continues: Behold, the disciples now unbind the one whom the Master had raised from death. For if the disciples had unbound Lazarus while he was still dead, they would have displayed a stench rather than power.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex qua consideratione nobis intuendum est, quod illos debemus per pastoralem auctoritatem solvere, quos auctorem nostrum cognoscimus per resuscitationis gratiam vivificare: quae nimirum vivificatio ante operationem rectitudinis in ipsa jam cognovimus confessione peccatorum: unde et ipsi mortuo nequaquam dicitur: Revivisce, sed, Veni foras; ac si aperte cuilibet mortuo in culpa diceretur: Foras jam per confessionem egredere, qui apud te interius per negligentiam lates.
chunks.english: From this consideration we must understand that we ought to loose through pastoral authority only those whom we know our Lord has given life through the grace of resurrection. We recognize this giving of life, which comes before the work of righteousness, already in the confession of sins itself. This is why the dead man is not told: Come back to life, but rather: Come out. It is as if anyone dead in sin were being told plainly: Come out now through confession, you who hide within yourself through negligence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Veniat itaque foras, id est, culpam confiteatur peccator; venientem vero foras solvant discipuli, ut pastores Ecclesiae ei poenam relaxent, qui non erubuit confiteri quod fecit.
chunks.english: Let the sinner come out, that is, let him confess his fault. And as he comes out, let the disciples unbind him, so that the pastors of the Church may release the penalty for one who was not ashamed to confess what he had done.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item: Sed utrum juste alliget pastor, pastoris tamen sententia gregi timenda est, ne is, qui subest, et cum injuste forsitan ligatur, ipsam obligationis sententiam ex alia culpa mereatur.
chunks.english: Gregory says further: But whether the pastor binds justly or not, the pastor's sentence should still be feared by the flock, lest the one who is subject, even when perhaps bound unjustly, may deserve that very sentence of binding for some other fault.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item: Qui sub manu pastoris est, timeat ligari vel juste vel injuste; nec pastoris sui judicium temere reprehendat, ne, etsi injuste ligatus est, ex ipsa tumidae reprehensionis superbia culpa, quae non erat, fiat.
chunks.english: He continues: Let whoever is under the hand of a pastor fear being bound, whether justly or unjustly. And let him not rashly criticize his pastor's judgment, lest even if he was bound unjustly, a fault that was not there before may arise from the very pride of his arrogant criticism.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex his Gregorii dictis et divina auctoritatis exemplis liquidum est nihil episcoporum sententiam valere, si ab aequitate discrepat divina, juxta illud propheticum mortificare vel vivificare volentes quos non possunt.
chunks.english: From these statements of Gregory and from examples of divine authority, it is clear that the sentence of bishops has no force if it deviates from divine equity, according to that prophetic statement about wanting to kill or give life to those whom they cannot.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui episcoporum quoque sententia ab ipsorum communione privantur, cum subjectos injuste a communione sua privare praesumpserint.
chunks.english: Those bishops who have presumed to deprive their subjects unjustly of communion are themselves deprived of communion by the sentence of bishops.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde Africanum concilium CCX: Ut non temere quemquam communione privet episcopus; et quandiu excommunicato suus non communicaret episcopus, eidem episcopo ab aliis non communicetur episcopis; ut magis episcopus caveat, ne dicat in quemquam, quod aliis documentis convincere non potest.
chunks.english: Thus the African Council, canon two hundred ten, states: Let no bishop rashly deprive anyone of communion. And as long as a bishop does not communicate with someone he has excommunicated, let that bishop not be communicated with by other bishops. This is so that a bishop may be more cautious not to pronounce against anyone what he cannot prove by other evidence.
chunks.notes: End of work
